And if you actually look at the results that we teed up in terms of laser unit placements in Q2, they were not materially different than what we had expected going into Q2.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Toni Sacconaghi with Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Toni Sacconaghi with Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mark, your services growth rate has been about 10 points lower than the company average in each of the last two quarters and then negative in total at constant currency. I think your long-run outlook is for services to grow roughly in line with the compan
componenttext: Mark, your services growth rate has been about 10 points lower than the company average in each of the last two quarters and then negative in total at constant currency. I think your long-run outlook is for services to grow roughly in line with the company average at around mid-single digits. You're now year and half into EDS, do you still have high conviction in that? And I understand there's a cyclical part of services, but much of your Services business, namely your Support and your Outsourcing businesses, are backlog driven, and so they don't really change very quickly. Can you give us your perspective on how we should think about the longer-term services growth rate? And to the degree that we are going to see something that's closer to the company average, when do we begin to see that and why?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure that's within the rules, Toni. But let me take a crack in your services one. So I think the answer to your question is, yes. I mean, we feel really good about the Services business all in. Now remember, you've got a blend of technology servic
componenttext: I'm not sure that's within the rules, Toni. But let me take a crack in your services one. So I think the answer to your question is, yes. I mean, we feel really good about the Services business all in. Now remember, you've got a blend of technology services and what you would think of is more outsourcing services around apps and ITO in the same bucket there. And the maintenance piece of the business does react more of a hardware sales and has a lagging effect on hardware sales in terms of growth, so that's sort of one point. Second, we've been spending a lot of time getting the business right. We have seen very strong improvement in our pipeline. We exited the year with very strong signings. We expect to have a very strong signings here this year, Toni. So when you look at our pipeline and you look at where we're at, we feel very good about the position of the business. Now let me go further just to give you a little bit more color. We have spent a lot of time over the past year and a half, really operationalizing the business, getting underneath issues in the business, opportunities in the business. And I think the team, for the most part, has done a very good job. We certainly improved our profitability, improved our cost structure, better aligned our costs with our revenue. That said, as what happens in most things, as we've gotten deeper into details, the opportunity we think to be very open with you is even better. And we're in the process working through this right now. These are things like how we automate and drive forward our data centers. How we align our job our tool strategy going forward. And I won't go into too much details because of the time on the call, but I will in the future period of time. There are immaterial opportunities for us in the business to improve it, and we will invest into that to get that right and we think that plays long run to our opportunity to grow the business and our opportunity to scale the business. So don't take anything away from this other than we think we got a major opportunity in the business. We feel very good about the position of it, Toni, and I think, you are right in your analytic. I wouldn't necessarily drive it to this hardware result in terms of driving the Services businesses or those kind of growth rates, but we certainly expected to grow at and above market.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And actually, Toni, for this quarter, we believe we grew roughly in line with markets. You saw the acceleration in ITO. We were up 6%, that's really reflecting the strong signings growth that we had basically coming out of 2009. On the Apps Services side,
componenttext: And actually, Toni, for this quarter, we believe we grew roughly in line with markets. You saw the acceleration in ITO. We were up 6%, that's really reflecting the strong signings growth that we had basically coming out of 2009. On the Apps Services side, it's been softer, although, as I mentioned in my prepared remarks, the signings in Application Services this quarter were up significantly. And so we should see an acceleration from a revenue perspective in that space as well in the second half.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Cathie, can you share with us your assumptions on what dilutions to non-GAAP earnings will be from 3Com and for Palm? What are you including in your forecast? And then for currency, what's your year-over-year currency assumption that 125 euro for Q3? Your
componenttext: Cathie, can you share with us your assumptions on what dilutions to non-GAAP earnings will be from 3Com and for Palm? What are you including in your forecast? And then for currency, what's your year-over-year currency assumption that 125 euro for Q3? Your impact from currency this quarter was significantly different than I have modeled, so I'd like to try and understand how you're thinking about your 125 euro all in for the company year-over-year in Q3.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: So on the 3Com, in our guidance, we've got $0.01 of dilution in Q3. For Palm, it's mostly in Q4 and it's a few cents we talked about. It's completely included in our guidance, so you don't have to worry about anything running away on us from a dilution pe
componenttext: So on the 3Com, in our guidance, we've got $0.01 of dilution in Q3. For Palm, it's mostly in Q4 and it's a few cents we talked about. It's completely included in our guidance, so you don't have to worry about anything running away on us from a dilution perspective on Palm. In terms of our currency assumption, we have modeled our business on a go-forward basis at basically a mid-120s euro. And that gives us a sequential headwind from Q2 to Q3 of roughly two points, and a sequential headwind from Q3 to Q4 of roughly one point.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Bailey of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Bailey of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: What are you seeing right now that makes you more, or less confident that we'll see a corporate PC upgrade cycle starting this year? And how should we think about the ramp in demand through the end of this year and into next year?
componenttext: What are you seeing right now that makes you more, or less confident that we'll see a corporate PC upgrade cycle starting this year? And how should we think about the ramp in demand through the end of this year and into next year?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Basically, we thought commercial clients grow 19% this quarter and that was led by 47% workstation growth. The workstation growth was heavily financial services industry which may tend to be more early adopter, and then broadly, around commercial SMB spac
componenttext: Basically, we thought commercial clients grow 19% this quarter and that was led by 47% workstation growth. The workstation growth was heavily financial services industry which may tend to be more early adopter, and then broadly, around commercial SMB space. And we've always thought that the refresh would start with consumers, then go to SMB and then go to corporate.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: David, listen, I think, we've seen this already going on a bit and we expect to see some more of it. We obviously had very strong workstation growth in the quarter. We had very strong desktop business, desktop growth in the quarter. When we look at what's
componenttext: David, listen, I think, we've seen this already going on a bit and we expect to see some more of it. We obviously had very strong workstation growth in the quarter. We had very strong desktop business, desktop growth in the quarter. When we look at what's coming off from data perspective, we gained eight points of share in the U.S. enterprise in the last quarter. That's second or third quarter that we've seen very large gains in terms of enterprise share and that put us in a pretty good position. We think that if this corporate refresh accelerates, this will be a very good news for us. Now what we've modeled, frankly, David, is more of the same. We have not modeled some big corporate refresh coming that sort of sequentially better than what we've seen. What we have seen, though, is some improvements in our funnel, some improvements in our performance in the areas that I've described, some quicker times to decisions. That's a very important thing and the fact that decision seems to be getting made a little bit faster than they were a year ago. But there is a spike, obviously, given the share position and the things that we're describing, there certainly would be good news.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Keith Bachman of Bank of Montreal.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Keith Bachman of Bank of Montreal.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask two questions on margins if I could, Mark. The first is related to the last comment. It seems like ASP erosions on PCs with perhaps netbook slowing a little bit, has slowed. And how does that make you think about your PC margins as you loo
componenttext: I wanted to ask two questions on margins if I could, Mark. The first is related to the last comment. It seems like ASP erosions on PCs with perhaps netbook slowing a little bit, has slowed. And how does that make you think about your PC margins as you look out over the next couple of quarters with mix and ASPs impacting? And the second question is similar on Services. If, in fact, the Services business picks up a little bit as you alluded to from Toni's questions, how should we be thinking about the Services margins as we look out to the balance of the year?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of points, and I think, again, you don't want to react to any one single metric in these businesses, Keith. But I agree with your conclusion that ASPs have improved. Some of that is frankly the commodity environment. And the commodity environment
componenttext: A couple of points, and I think, again, you don't want to react to any one single metric in these businesses, Keith. But I agree with your conclusion that ASPs have improved. Some of that is frankly the commodity environment. And the commodity environment, as you can imagine in 2009, many of the commodity providers, particularly memory providers, really clamped down on CapEx. And so when you look at their capacity today, their capacity is low as demand is increasing. That, of course, increases the price in some of the commodity areas. Typically, as you know, Keith, we do very well in environments like this from a procurement perspective and alignment of supply. That said, there is a passing through of those commodity prices, which you've seen sort of across the board for most companies in the industry, and that is having some effect on ASPs. In addition to your point, some of these sort of better performance you're seeing in some areas like business desktops and workstations, that mix is also affecting the aggregate ASP as well, so that is also a benefit that you're seeing going on in the quarter and what's transpiring. In terms of margins, we'll continue to balance growth and profitability, and make sure we hit the right optimal point within it. Remember, for us, Keith, we think about the PC business more broadly than we do the PC business just an isolation. The PC business really is the procurement arm for almost the entire company from a product perspective. We leverage the common parts across almost all of our infrastructure, so for us, we think about it not just in the context of PSG operating performance but the leverage in the position that gives to the entire company. So I think it's generally good news in terms of the growth that you're seeing in the market, the ASP improvement you're seeing. There is a tighter commodity environment and we'll continue to balance it as we go forward in terms of optimizing growth and profitability.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Shannon Cross of Cross Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Shannon Cross of Cross Research.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you talk a little bit about what you're seeing, or your thoughts on what we're seeing in the software industry with regards to the acquisitions? You had a 50 [ph] for Sybase. It sounds like Symantec's taking out their assigned security business. Jus
componenttext: Could you talk a little bit about what you're seeing, or your thoughts on what we're seeing in the software industry with regards to the acquisitions? You had a 50 [ph] for Sybase. It sounds like Symantec's taking out their assigned security business. Just how are you sort of thinking about software and your position and where you might want to go?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we continue, Shannon, to be very excited about the opportunities that sit in the management space, management again of servers, the management of PCs, the management of storage, the management of networks, the security around it. I mean, we think
componenttext: I think we continue, Shannon, to be very excited about the opportunities that sit in the management space, management again of servers, the management of PCs, the management of storage, the management of networks, the security around it. I mean, we think these are big -- remember, when we talk about security, Shannon, we don't just talk about a product. We talk about a whole gamut of capabilities. Cathie mentioned earlier TippingPoint on the data intrusion side, but it's security on the product level, on the services level, on the architectural level. And so we continue to focus in these areas. Some of the acquisitions that you've described and I won't go into them are frankly not that intriguing to us and are not that relevant to our strategy, which really is around this whole automation management plays, that we think directly affects our Converged Infrastructure business on one side, and also helps automate our services on the other. And so our Software business has three strategic objectives for HP. We try to sell them as individual products in data center transformation. We try to integrate them with our Converged Infrastructure. At the same time, we try to use them as the baseline for our tools capability to automate our services. And we try to do all three at the same time and we'll continue to look for organic ways and other ways to continue to improve our capabilities in those areas. And that's what we're thinking about.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mark, could you talk a little bit about your thoughts on the tablet, given what we're seeing with the iPad and then clearly your Palm acquisition?
componenttext: Mark, could you talk a little bit about your thoughts on the tablet, given what we're seeing with the iPad and then clearly your Palm acquisition?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, I think we think there is a market there and we expect to be a participant in that market, so we feel very good. We've, again, never felt, like the market was one product or one device would become ubiquitous. We believe that the world is go
componenttext: Well, I mean, I think we think there is a market there and we expect to be a participant in that market, so we feel very good. We've, again, never felt, like the market was one product or one device would become ubiquitous. We believe that the world is going to a series, more and more mobility, not less, and more and more differentiation between what users want to have in terms of capability, all the way from a purely voice product, up through a smartphone capability, through a tablet, through a notebook, and we expect to play across that gamut of capabilities the customers want, and that's where we expect to go.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Craig of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Craig of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Cathie, can you maybe look at the IPG margins over the next couple of quarters, as you see the hardware increasing perhaps as a percentage of sales, particularly given the laser growth that you're looking at? How does that impact the margins of that busin
componenttext: Cathie, can you maybe look at the IPG margins over the next couple of quarters, as you see the hardware increasing perhaps as a percentage of sales, particularly given the laser growth that you're looking at? How does that impact the margins of that business and your thought process around the range of what possible margins could be in there throughout the rest of the year?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm not really going to update the guidance for the full year beyond the 15% to 17% that we think are kind of the margins for IPG this year. We believe we can definitely manage anything that's coming down the pike right now in that range. The hardware uni
componenttext: I'm not really going to update the guidance for the full year beyond the 15% to 17% that we think are kind of the margins for IPG this year. We believe we can definitely manage anything that's coming down the pike right now in that range. The hardware unit placements can uptick significantly. We still absorb it, and that's because it just done a great job of frankly making operating IPG in a tighter way and getting supply chain costs and OpEx costs out of the cost structure, so they were able to absorb these unit placements and still maintain industry-leading profitability.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think to Cathie's point, there's a big point, Scott. I mean, in a very strange way, 2009 was really a blessing for us and I'll emphasize in a strange way. Because it really got us sharper and IPG is a really good example of that. We felt we're going in
componenttext: I think to Cathie's point, there's a big point, Scott. I mean, in a very strange way, 2009 was really a blessing for us and I'll emphasize in a strange way. Because it really got us sharper and IPG is a really good example of that. We felt we're going in pretty sharp and we certainly sharpened up. Our ability now to deal with some of these issues has just given us more flexibility that we do the kind of unit performance that we've talked about here. For the full year, forget this quarter, that quarter, but when you look at the full year unit performance and the opportunities we have in terms of placements. Again, understand, Scott, we've done this while investing and placing these retail photo kiosks. So I want to make sure this is no trivial issue that we've been able to absorb the start-up of the Managed Print Services businesses. We've been able to install these retail photo kiosks, which are very similar to the printer models, just bigger units. We've forecast the growth -- take the unit growth in inkjet, the forecast that we have in laser and do all that within the targeted margins that we've described. This has given us a level of flexibility. But frankly, if you went back three or four years, we simply couldn't have done this. And so this is a big deal for us.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Scott, it's not just about the P&L. It's also about working capital management. We're able to operate with much lower channel inventory levels today because we've improved our efficiency on that side. And then also, the owned inventory levels are down
componenttext: And Scott, it's not just about the P&L. It's also about working capital management. We're able to operate with much lower channel inventory levels today because we've improved our efficiency on that side. And then also, the owned inventory levels are down significantly year-on-year, again, this quarter. And we expect continued improvement in that space. And so it's really the entire ecosystem of the IPG business, both the income statement and the balance sheet and our partners.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Aaron Rakers of Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Aaron Rakers of Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess another operating margin question for me. On the enterprise side of the business, obviously, we saw an even stronger mix towards your industry standard servers. And we're still generally sitting in front of what looks to be a high-end product cycl
componenttext: I guess another operating margin question for me. On the enterprise side of the business, obviously, we saw an even stronger mix towards your industry standard servers. And we're still generally sitting in front of what looks to be a high-end product cycle in that product category going forward, yet, you guys did a 12.6% operating margin versus your target of 11% to 12%. I'm trying to understand, do we think about 11% to 12%, or do we think about a sustainable trend above that? And if not above that, why might not that be?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you look at the quarter, we had roughly 30% operating leverage in ESS this quarter, and that's about what we had last quarter, too, I think it was about 33% last quarter. But obviously, exactly how much that continues will depend on the mix in the busi
componenttext: If you look at the quarter, we had roughly 30% operating leverage in ESS this quarter, and that's about what we had last quarter, too, I think it was about 33% last quarter. But obviously, exactly how much that continues will depend on the mix in the business. Because the gross margin profile of Industry Standard Servers is very different than Business Critical Systems which, by the way, is very different than Virtual Connect, which is also in the Enterprise Server and Storage Group.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you're right what you say though. I mean, the fact is that we are introducing a new Business Critical System, it is in Q3 though, mostly the mid-range part. The new Superdome is actually showing up at the end of Q3, really more of Q4. And I
componenttext: Well, I think you're right what you say though. I mean, the fact is that we are introducing a new Business Critical System, it is in Q3 though, mostly the mid-range part. The new Superdome is actually showing up at the end of Q3, really more of Q4. And I think, to Cathie's point, you're going to continue to see a mix in combination of we think very strong growth in the Industry Standard Server blade market, combined with Virtual Connect, combined again. There's also a transformation going on at Storage as I mentioned earlier. I mean, we've got very strong growth going on in iSCSI part of the market, which we think is a very attractive part of the market, where we've seen significant growth occurring. So I do think you're right. We feel very good about the new product release. That probably has more of an impact to us in the back half of the year than it does in Q3. But again, I think to Cathie's point, when you get 30% leverage like what we're seeing, ESN has done a lot of what we've described in IPG, working hard. They're not quite to the same position that IPG is now, but they're on a same path to do more work in its operations and its supply chain that we can get more flexibility and more leverage, as we bring in a assortment of products, we think to market that are pretty darn exciting.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Alexander of Raymond James.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Alexander of Raymond James.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just to go back to the Laser business, sorry for beating a dead horse, but could you just be a little more specific on what cost the core laser units to be down 8% after growing 11% last quarter, while the market growth was actually accelerating? I guess,
componenttext: Just to go back to the Laser business, sorry for beating a dead horse, but could you just be a little more specific on what cost the core laser units to be down 8% after growing 11% last quarter, while the market growth was actually accelerating? I guess, what specifically needs to improve? It seems like the product constraints have been prevalent for multiple quarters, so is any of these intentional seeding of market share, due to low price points by competitors? And then if you could just comment on supplies, did the growth in local currency accelerate in line with your expectations, and do you think that'll continue for the balance of the year as placements for lasers pickup?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the laser side, it's really capacity. Just the inability to get as many laser units as we wanted and the demand that we had for them. So two things have happened. One is, demand has picked up and improved more than what we have expected. That's good ne
componenttext: On the laser side, it's really capacity. Just the inability to get as many laser units as we wanted and the demand that we had for them. So two things have happened. One is, demand has picked up and improved more than what we have expected. That's good news and it's also a bad news, because we haven't been able to get the capacity. We have a very strong backlog coming out of Q2. And like I said earlier, what happened in Q2 in terms of the laser unit decline is not really a surprise to us. It's materially what we had expected going into Q2. This was always going to be a back half, very strong back half unit placement for lasers in order to get to the double digits for the year that we believe is very doable.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, Brian, this is where we expected to be, roughly speaking. There was no sort of surprise to us. I would characterize it differently. We would like to have had more. That's probably the better way to think about it. And let me make sure I'm cle
componenttext:
Yes, I mean, Brian, this is where we expected to be, roughly speaking. There was no sort of surprise to us. I would characterize it differently. We would like to have had more. That's probably the better way to think about it. And let me make sure I'm clear with you, no, we did not do any hold back, because the price points quite the opposite. We were pushing as hard as we could towards the end of the quarter and we're pushing as hard as we can right now. The demand is strong. So to Cathie's point, that's the good news. The bad news is, we haven't been able to fulfill as much as customers want. The brand loyalty to HP is just -- unless you're here feeling it, you wouldn't get it. I mean, it is just amazing how our partners and our customers stick with us on this, and we're going to get better at this. And I'm telling you, I think, Q3 will be turn on it. To your point about supplies, yes, supplies have been strong. I mean, it's good news and I think it's also not just the unit placements as we've talked before, Brian. Getting the right units placed is actually more important than the unit number of units to get placed. And to some degree, I think you saw that show up in Q2 as well. When you look at the ASPs in the Laser business, let me flip it around. What we were able to focus on was getting the right units out. And that did pay dividends within the context of a number that clearly, we just wish was better. 
Let me wrap it up here. Listen, I think the conclusion of it, for us, is we feel very good about the broad-based growth in the quarter. 13% growth for us, is we think a good result. Not only the fact that we grew 13%, but the fact that it was contributed through across regions and across our businesses we think was extremely positive. 
We are a stronger company today and I want to emphasize that based on our portfolio, our scale and our consistent execution. At the same time, we have more work to do to transform ourselves to reach our potentials. So as good as we feel in some respects about what we've done, we are still not to our full potential, and we feel good about our position which gives us the confidence as we've described here, to raise our outlook from where we previously had it. So thank you all for joining us. We do appreciate it.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, May 18, 2010
