componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, this concludes our call for today. Thank you very much. You may now disconnect. Have a great day.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the third quarter 2010 Hewlett-Packard earnings conference call. (Operator Instructions) I would now like to turn the presentation over to your host for today's call, Mr. Jim Burns, Vice President of Investor Relations.
componenttext: Welcome to the third quarter 2010 Hewlett-Packard earnings conference call. (Operator Instructions) I would now like to turn the presentation over to your host for today's call, Mr. Jim Burns, Vice President of Investor Relations.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. Welcome to our third quarter earnings conference call with Cathie Lesjak, CFO and Interim CEO; Todd Bradley from the Personal Systems Group; Ann Livermore from HP's Enterprise Business; and V. J. who runs the Imaging and Printing Group. Th
componenttext:
Good afternoon. Welcome to our third quarter earnings conference call with Cathie Lesjak, CFO and Interim CEO; Todd Bradley from the Personal Systems Group; Ann Livermore from HP's Enterprise Business; and V. J. who runs the Imaging and Printing Group. This call is being webcast. A replay of the webcast will be available shortly after the call for approximately one year.
Some information provided during this call may include forward-looking statements that are based on certain assumptions and are subject to a number of risks and uncertainties, and actual future results may vary materially. Please refer to the risks described in HP's SEC reports, including our most recent Form 10-Q.
The financial information discussed in connection with this call, including tax-related items, reflects estimates based on information available at this time and could differ materially from the amounts ultimately reported in HP's third quarter Form 10-Q. Earnings, operating margins and similar items at the company level are sometimes expressed on a non-GAAP basis and have been adjusted to exclude certain items including amortization of purchased intangibles, restructuring charges and acquisition-related charges.
The comparable GAAP financial information and a reconciliation of non-GAAP amounts to GAAP are included in the tables and in the slide presentation accompanying today's earnings release, both of which are available on the HP Investor Relations webpage at hp.com.
With that, I'll now turn the call over to Cathie.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon and thank you for joining us. Q3 was another strong quarter of profitable growth for Hewlett-Packard that highlights our consistent broad-based performance. We grew revenue 11%, expanded operating margins 30 basis points versus the prior ye
componenttext:
Good afternoon and thank you for joining us. Q3 was another strong quarter of profitable growth for Hewlett-Packard that highlights our consistent broad-based performance. We grew revenue 11%, expanded operating margins 30 basis points versus the prior year and grew non-GAAP EPS by 17% to $1.08.
HP is a trusted partner with strong relationships across its customer base. Our portfolio, made up of hardware, software and services, is winning today. But more importantly, our customers recognize HP's position for the future in the data center and converged infrastructure, in connected and mobile devices, in our imaging portfolio and in the breadth of our services offerings.
In Q3, we had balanced geographic performance with revenue in each region growing faster than normal seasonality. Americas was up 12%, EMEA up 9%, and Asia Pacific grew 14%. We saw solid growth across both developed and developing economies.
Our Q3 results also demonstrate good balanced growth across IPG, PSG and our Enterprise Business with solid double-digit growth in our hardware businesses. We are capitalizing on commercial spending with ISS revenue of 31%, storage up 10%, core growth about 42%, IPG commercial up 28% and PSG commercial up 25%. Additionally, we experienced strong services signings in the quarter and increased Enterprise services hardware revenue pull-through by over 50%.
On the expense side, we continue to aggressively improve our productivity. We have significant savings still to be captured in our services, supply chain and real estate initiative. At the same time, we are increasing our investments in R&D and sales and marketing. We see attractive opportunities to take our portfolio to the next level and are focused on increasing our coverage of the $1.3 trillion market.
Before discussing our detailed financial results, let me just summarize our unique position in the market and our sustainable competitive advantages. As our results demonstrate, we continue to leverage our scale and reach to serve customers around the world and drive increased productivity. We are using our financial strength to make balanced investments in growth, efficiency and in effective capital structure.
We are delivering leading technology, products and solutions to our customers. And we will continue to leverage our talented management team to deliver consistent execution.
Now let's take a deeper dive into our numbers, beginning with the P&L. Revenue for the third quarter totaled $30.7 billion. We added $3.1 billion to the topline, delivering 11% growth, including almost a point of favorable currency impact. This was the strongest constant currency growth since 2008.
The third quarter gross margin was 23.8%, up slightly from the prior year and up 30 basis points sequentially. Operating expenses increased 10% to $3.9 billion, as we accelerated investments to drive long-term growth, including increases in R&D and building out our Enterprise sales force. Excluding the impact of the DOJ legal settlement, operating expenses increased 8%.
Non-GAAP operating profit increased 14% year-on-year to $3.4 billion, with operating margin expansion of 30 basis points. Other income and expense yielded a net expense of $135 million due primarily to currency losses.
Non-GAAP net income improved to $2.6 billion, and non-GAAP diluted earnings per share increased 17% to $1.08, including the charge of approximately $0.02 relating to the previously announced Department of Justice settlement.
Let's look at the details of our performance by business. Revenue in the Imaging and Printing business grew 9% to $6.2 billion, fueled by year-over-year unit shipment growth of 16% and supplies revenue growth of 5%. Commercial hardware revenue increased 28%, while consumer hardware revenue grew 4% compared with the prior-year quarter. Segment operating profit totaled $1 billion or 16.9% of revenue.
We continue to lead the market with innovative new products. In June, we launched the ePrint platform and the ePrintCenter and announced we were expanding our portfolio of web-connected printers to include all printers above $99. This strategy is driving success with third quarter consumer inkjet hardware shipments up 9% year-over-year, led by 64% growth in wireless printers and Officejet growth of 16%.
In addition, our retail publishing footprint continues to expand both in the U.S. and across the world. Commercial printer unit shipments grew 44% with stronger mono and color laser shipments, as hardware availability improved significantly from the prior quarter.
We continue to see strong momentum in our growth initiatives in the Enterprise and commercial print markets. Both graphic arts and managed print services grew double digits. Multi-function printer shipments increased 47% over the prior-year period, and HP Indigo digital presses page volume was up 22%. We will continue to aggressively target these markets, leveraging our technology leadership to drive the shift from analog to digital printing.
Turning to Personal Systems, PSG revenue increased 17% from the prior year to $9.9 billion with total unit shipments growing 12%. Segment operating profit totaled $469 million or 4.7% of revenue, as PSG continues to deliver solid performance, driven by our innovative product portfolio, scale and global reach.
Notebook and desktop revenues were up 10% and 27% respectively, and workstation revenue increased 54%. This strong workstation performance was driven by our new products with their attractive price performance. PSG average unit prices increased 5% from the prior year and 1% sequentially.
Our initiatives to extend our position in the commercial segment are paying off, with commercial client revenue increasing 25%. Our market leadership in commercial PCs and continued share gains in the U.S. Enterprise segment position us well for the PC refresh cycle that we're seeing in both SMB and corporate enterprise.
Finally, we are pleased to have closed the Palm acquisition at the beginning of July, which gives us the ability to leverage the webOS in a variety of connected mobile devices.
Services delivered revenue of $8.6 billion, up 1% from the prior year. Within services, application services increased 4% with growth coming from both new customer accounts and the install base. IT outsourcing and business process outsourcing each increased 1%, and the technology services business declined 1%.
We have strong growth in signings due to renewals by some of our largest customers, and the trailing 12-month book-to-bill remains comfortably greater than 1. As I indicated earlier in my remarks, we are also seeing more HP products pull through into our enterprise service accounts, and we expect this trend to continue.
Services segment operating profit in the quarter increased to $1.4 billion or 15.9% of revenue, up 60 basis points from the prior year, driven by improvements in service delivery.
HP software revenue was $853 million, up 2% when compared with the prior year. BTO increased 3%, led by growth in license revenues. The software business expanded its operating margins by 310 basis points to 21.2%.
On Tuesday of this week, we announced an agreement to acquire Fortify Software. This addition to HPs portfolio complements our existing dynamic application security solution, and strengthens our leadership position in application and information security.
Enterprise storage and server revenue was $4.4 billion, up 19% compared with the prior year with balanced double digit growth across every region. This quarter, the business delivered $549 million in operating profit and an operating margin of 12.3%, an increase of 210 basis points from the prior year.
The ESS results were driven by strong performance in ISS and ESS blades, which grew 31% and 29% respectively. Storage revenue increased 10% from the prior year, with triple-digit growth in our scale out ICSI products based on technology acquired from LeftHand Networks.
Business critical systems revenue declined 15% ahead of our new Superdome products which starts shipping in Q4. This quarter, we launched several new products in ESS. I June, we introduced new ProLiant G7 servers, significant enhancements to blade system offerings and our new smart grid technologies which increased the energy benefits for customers by making the datacenter more efficient.
Finally, in July we expanded our storage offerings with the launch of our StoreOnce deduplication products developed by HP Labs.
Turning to our networking business. With the close of 3Com in Q2, we are accelerating our investments in networking. HP Networking, which is reported in the Corporate Investments segment, recorded organic growth of 42%, or total growth of 198% including 3Com, which was ahead of plans.
In the last 90 days, we have seen significant interest in our HP Networking datacenter solutions. Three hundred of our top 1000 customers have initiated proof of concept. Among the customers deploying HP Networking solutions this quarter are Marriott, DreamWorks and the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services.
HP Financial Services continues to deliver very strong consistent results. In the third quarter, financing revenue grew 14% to $764 million and generated operating margins of 9.4%, up 150 basis points from the prior year.
Now on to the balance sheet and cash flow. Our balance sheet remained strong with solid working capital management. We closed the quarter with total gross cash of $14.8 billion. Our third quarter cash conversion cycle was 17 days, down a day from a year ago with day sales outstanding down two days, inventories up three days and days payable up two days.
Channel inventories in ESS and IPG are in good shape. PSG channel inventory is a few days higher than we'd like, and we expect to bring it down in Q4.
We generated operating cash flow of $3.3 billion and free cash flow of $2.2 billion.
During the third quarter we returned $2.6 billion to shareholders through share repurchases and reduced our weighted average shares outstanding by $30 million sequentially. And the end of the quarter we had roughly $4.9 billion remaining in our current share repurchase authorization, and we expect to remain active in our shares through the end of the fiscal year.
Finally, we paid dividends totaling $205 million.
And now, a few comments on our outlook for the fourth quarter and the full year. We expect Q4 fiscal 2010 revenues to be $32.5 billion to $32.7 billion. Included in this outlook is approximately 1 point of negative currency impact compared with the prior year.
For the full year, we are raising our outlook to $125.3 billion to $125.5 billion, up approximately 9.5% from the prior year. Regarding earnings, there are few variables to keep in mind. We will continue to fund investments to drive long term growth initiatives. We expect O&E expense of about $0.05 per share, a tax rate of approximately 22% and a sequential decline in weighted average shares outstanding similar to what we drove in the third quarter.
With that in mind, we expect fourth quarter non-GAAP EPS in the range of $1.25 to $1.27. For the full year, we are raising our outlook and now expect non-GAAP EPS of $4.49 to $4.51, representing growth of approximately 17% for the fiscal year.
In summary, we feel good about our broad-based performance in Q3. We are well positioned in the market, and our full year outlook reflects our strength and ability to execute.
With that, we will now open the call for your questions.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: (Operator Instructions) And your question comes from the line of Brian Alexander of Raymond James.
componenttext: (Operator Instructions) And your question comes from the line of Brian Alexander of Raymond James.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Cathie, you mentioned increase in investments in R&D and sales and marketing in your prepared remarks. It seems like quite a few investors believe that the next CEO might decide to noticeably step up the pace of investment as they assume the company has s
componenttext:
Cathie, you mentioned increase in investments in R&D and sales and marketing in your prepared remarks. It seems like quite a few investors believe that the next CEO might decide to noticeably step up the pace of investment as they assume the company has systematically underinvested in recent quarters. So the concern is this would create near term margin pressure and perhaps even a reset of earnings expectations.
So I'm just wondering if you could address the premise that HP's been under-investing, and do you plan to reflect what the possibility of the next CEO investing more aggressively when you provide the FY11 outlook at your analysts day?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Brian, we have not under-invested in R&D. I think that's probably the short answer to that. And we've got a number of proof points, and I'll actually ask in the minute, Ann and VJ to comment on that. But I think what is important is to think about the fac
componenttext:
Brian, we have not under-invested in R&D. I think that's probably the short answer to that. And we've got a number of proof points, and I'll actually ask in the minute, Ann and VJ to comment on that. But I think what is important is to think about the fact that we've got three year plans out there. Three year plans that are supported by the board that include acceleration in both R&D and sales to drive growth, and those investments are funded through the vast number of productivity initiatives that we've got kind of in flight already. Plus those that are still to come, that give us a real opportunity to not only have health growth, but also grow EPS even faster than revenue growth.
So I don't think that there is an issue there at all. And maybe I'll ask again, Ann and VJ to comment on some of the R&D investments that we've made and the success we've had there over the last few years.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, if you look at Q3, during the quarter we had a set of product introductions for the Enterprise Servers, Storage and Networking business that was the largest quarter ever, and this was the result of R&D investments that have been made quarters and ye
componenttext:
Sure, if you look at Q3, during the quarter we had a set of product introductions for the Enterprise Servers, Storage and Networking business that was the largest quarter ever, and this was the result of R&D investments that have been made quarters and years in advance.
So we announced in June or launched in June the G7 server for a new offering in our ProLiant family. We had significant enhancements that were made to our BladeSystem's offerings. And you also saw a whole new smart grid technology that we introduced. This is focused on helping clients be able to improve the energy efficiency of their data centers.
On top of all that, we also launched StoreOnce, which is the deduplication product that was created in HP labs and then brought through my product development team. This offering is twice as good as anything else in the market from a price performance perspective for deduplication.
And then just to crown it all off, we had our networking business with HP ProCurve, which we've been investing from an R&D perspective, growing 42%. So I think all those things are trying to see R&D that we've been doing and will certainly continue to do.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: At iPaq, we introduced our next generation of Webpress, we got a phenomenal feedback. On June 6, we introduced all of our new web connected printers at above $99; every single printer will have an email address. And we could see in the results we have two
componenttext:
At iPaq, we introduced our next generation of Webpress, we got a phenomenal feedback. On June 6, we introduced all of our new web connected printers at above $99; every single printer will have an email address. And we could see in the results we have two points of market share in Inkjet. We had 16% unit growth in every single category. We are increasing our market share.
So from an innovation point of view, we are on fire. As a matter of fact, the feedback that we get that the product portfolio that we have right now is the best in last six years.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ben Reitzes of Barclays Capital. You may proceed.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ben Reitzes of Barclays Capital. You may proceed.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Could you talk a little bit about what you're seeing in the businesses from this context? I think some might be surprised that a lot of the revenue upside was in services versus my model. And obviously there has been strength in Enterprise though and ther
componenttext: Could you talk a little bit about what you're seeing in the businesses from this context? I think some might be surprised that a lot of the revenue upside was in services versus my model. And obviously there has been strength in Enterprise though and there has been strength in printers for some. I just would have thought maybe supplies or some of the other things might have picked up more. I was wondering if there are shortages there and if you could kind of just talk about the segments a little more because I think PCs were a lot better than expected. And services revenue as well and some of the others looked like there might still be some shortages and what not heading into the next quarter.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Ben, in terms of supplies growth, we had 5% supplies growth year-over-year, on a constant currency basis, that was 8% supplies growth. So still quite strong supplies growth. And as we've talked on most of this year, we've had this roughly three points of
componenttext: Ben, in terms of supplies growth, we had 5% supplies growth year-over-year, on a constant currency basis, that was 8% supplies growth. So still quite strong supplies growth. And as we've talked on most of this year, we've had this roughly three points of currency headwind. And we see that continuing into Q4. So if you think about supply growth, we think about it in terms of kind of reported mid single digits. And on a constant currency, mid to high single digits for Q4.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And was there still constraint in the quarter?
componenttext: And was there still constraint in the quarter?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: No constraints. I think the LaserJet you could see 44% unit growth that we delivered. In a way, we have a tremendous demand here, the LaserJet brand is fantastic. And we are expecting in fourth quarter, at least 30% unit growth for the LaserJet. So we bel
componenttext: No constraints. I think the LaserJet you could see 44% unit growth that we delivered. In a way, we have a tremendous demand here, the LaserJet brand is fantastic. And we are expecting in fourth quarter, at least 30% unit growth for the LaserJet. So we believe that the demand is strong, they've continued to get out the availability. And in supplies, you'd also remember that we are gaining share against refill and reman. We are really driving our supplies sell out. We absolutely believe that putting more units now and valuable units and with web connectivity and the stuff that we are doing with ink in the office, we're going to continue to see very good growth.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Ben, this is Todd Bradley. I'd just add to V. J.'s comments, in our commercial markets we gained about eight points of share in the U.S. Enterprise. And we're seeing very, very good pull-through from our Enterprise Services. Our ASPs are up 5%, I think th
componenttext: Ben, this is Todd Bradley. I'd just add to V. J.'s comments, in our commercial markets we gained about eight points of share in the U.S. Enterprise. And we're seeing very, very good pull-through from our Enterprise Services. Our ASPs are up 5%, I think that demonstrates that customers are willing to pay for new and innovative products that we're bringing to market.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Cathie, can you just talk about the inventory in the quarter, up 12%, does that mean that you're expecting a big 4Q or were you happy with that number?
componenttext: Cathie, can you just talk about the inventory in the quarter, up 12%, does that mean that you're expecting a big 4Q or were you happy with that number?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm happy with the way we ended inventory, it was up three days year-on-year, and it was up for all good reasons. There were three main reasons. The first reason was better laser availability. The second one was we're putting more inventory on C, especial
componenttext: I'm happy with the way we ended inventory, it was up three days year-on-year, and it was up for all good reasons. There were three main reasons. The first reason was better laser availability. The second one was we're putting more inventory on C, especially in the PC category, which gives us a cost advantage. And then the third is that we've had good response, good growth in our POD business, which is basically data center in a container. And obviously, it takes more inventory to build out an entire data center before you ship it. So I'm very comfortable of where the inventory landed.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Richard Gardner of Citigroup.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Richard Gardner of Citigroup.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: I was hoping, Cathie, and perhaps, Todd, that you could talk about what's going on in the PC business, giving the sharp deceleration in unit growth that we saw in the quarter. I think this is the first quarter where you've lost market share in a number of
componenttext: I was hoping, Cathie, and perhaps, Todd, that you could talk about what's going on in the PC business, giving the sharp deceleration in unit growth that we saw in the quarter. I think this is the first quarter where you've lost market share in a number of years. So just curious to get your sense of whether this is more of the market situation or whether there were significant company specific events that took place during the quarter as well. And what your view on when you can get back to sort of market rate of growth for better is there?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Hey Rick this is Todd. The yardstick I use for PSG has been, and remains profitable growth. As you heard Cathie report, we had very solid revenue growth this quarter at 17%. And I think very good profitability at 4.7%. There is bad business to chase in th
componenttext:
Hey Rick this is Todd. The yardstick I use for PSG has been, and remains profitable growth. As you heard Cathie report, we had very solid revenue growth this quarter at 17%. And I think very good profitability at 4.7%. There is bad business to chase in the PC market, if market share is your primary and you're only goal. That's not what we're working on. Our scale, our global footprint, frankly the flexibility in the business will continue to be competitive differentiators for PSG and for HP overall.
The other point I'd make, just to repeat what I had said to Ben's comment was, we solved strength in our commercial markets. We gained eight points of share in the U.S. Enterprise where we're seeing very, very good pull-through from our Enterprise Services, our ASPs were up 5%, demonstrating customers willingness to pay for both innovative products and high quality products.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Could you characterize what you're seeing in the consumer PC market currently?
componenttext: Could you characterize what you're seeing in the consumer PC market currently?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we saw some softness in our consumer notebook market; and I call it consumer notebook market. I think back-to-school started somewhat late for us, but we've certainly seen it start. Though, I think a soft beginning but overall we're seeing things ar
componenttext: Well, we saw some softness in our consumer notebook market; and I call it consumer notebook market. I think back-to-school started somewhat late for us, but we've certainly seen it start. Though, I think a soft beginning but overall we're seeing things are on track.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Keith Bachman of Bank of Montreal. You may proceed.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Keith Bachman of Bank of Montreal. You may proceed.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: I want to ask Cathie and Ann about the Services business, and the focus of the question is, really, what's the growth rate potential? The revenue growth was up about 1%, my guess is probably flat on constant currency basis. And yet, the operating margins
componenttext: I want to ask Cathie and Ann about the Services business, and the focus of the question is, really, what's the growth rate potential? The revenue growth was up about 1%, my guess is probably flat on constant currency basis. And yet, the operating margins were about flattish over the last couple of quarters. Can it be a growth business? And then how does the remaining cost opportunities play out against that growth potential?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: As we look at the third quarter, it was the record signings quarter for us. And as you know, this business is driven by having solid pipelines that have quality deals as well as good quantity of deals. So we feel good about the pipeline that we have; we f
componenttext:
As we look at the third quarter, it was the record signings quarter for us. And as you know, this business is driven by having solid pipelines that have quality deals as well as good quantity of deals. So we feel good about the pipeline that we have; we feel good about the record signings that we had this quarter, that was driven both by a good renewals as well as some new signings. And then when we look at the trailing 12 month signing, and also the book-to-bill ratios, we feel that both of those are healthy numbers. So we feel good about all those things.
As we are finishing up with the first phase of the integration of EDS and HP, what we're doing now is increasing some of our sales resources, and also seeing a very nice improvement in the pull-through. So we care about our overall product position and our ability to sell more products as well as the ultimate growth of the Services business itself.
We do expect that we're going to be able to have this business at a point where it can outgrow the market, and that's going to be based on the sales coverage, improvements we're making as well as some offering adjustments that we are making.
When you look at the margin part of your question, we've performed right at the midpoint of what we said our guidance was of 15% to 17%. So with 15.9 we were right at that midpoint. We were up 60 basis points year-over-year. And yet we feel like even though we're at that range already, there's still a lot more work for us to do.
Back in June, at the beginning of the month we announced a new transformation initiative that we believe can take enterprise services to the next level. And what we communicated to you then that those activities that we are doing around consolidating datacenters, doing more tools deployment, driving more automation, reducing layers, that all these things could generate $500 million to $700 million of net savings by the end of FY '13. So we still feel very optimistic about those numbers that we gave you.
And then on top of it all, as you know having great costs allow you to bite more aggressively and at the same time deliver good margins. So we are always going to be working on the costs to achieve that. So we feel good about where we are at this point, and believe there is a lot of improvement still yet to do in the business.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And let me just take it just a tiny bit more tactical and just talk about the fact that in Q3 it was a bit of an investment quarter for us, and that you should see that the transformation starts to kick in, in Q4 and you'll see an uptick in margins starti
componenttext: And let me just take it just a tiny bit more tactical and just talk about the fact that in Q3 it was a bit of an investment quarter for us, and that you should see that the transformation starts to kick in, in Q4 and you'll see an uptick in margins starting in Q4.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Katy Huberty of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Katy Huberty of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Cathie, this is one of the strongest gross margins for the company in a number of years. Given the relative strength you are seeing in enterprise versus for instance consumer PCs which are lower margin and what's going on in the component cost environment
componenttext: Cathie, this is one of the strongest gross margins for the company in a number of years. Given the relative strength you are seeing in enterprise versus for instance consumer PCs which are lower margin and what's going on in the component cost environment, any reason to believe that this level isn't sustainable or you couldn't even grow off this space?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Katy, a couple of things; first off, the normal sequential pattern for gross margin is that Q4 margins pick up from Q3, and we don't expect any different pattern this year. On top of that the recent acquisitions that we've closed and/or announced are very
componenttext:
Katy, a couple of things; first off, the normal sequential pattern for gross margin is that Q4 margins pick up from Q3, and we don't expect any different pattern this year. On top of that the recent acquisitions that we've closed and/or announced are very positive for margins. For example, a lot of the strength in our gross margin this quarter came from the networking business, both in terms of increasing the mix. ProCurve grew 42% year-over-year.
Obviously we also added 3Com to the mix. But also, just rate improvements in that business as well.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And then if I may, just a quick follow up for Todd. You mentioned the consumer notebook weakness which may be partially attributed to strong tablet sales. When would you expect HP to participate in that category?
componenttext: And then if I may, just a quick follow up for Todd. You mentioned the consumer notebook weakness which may be partially attributed to strong tablet sales. When would you expect HP to participate in that category?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, as we look at tablet sales and slate sales that was a big part of the reason we acquired Palm. You'll see us with a Microsoft product out in the near future, and a webOS-based product in early 2011.
componenttext: Well, as we look at tablet sales and slate sales that was a big part of the reason we acquired Palm. You'll see us with a Microsoft product out in the near future, and a webOS-based product in early 2011.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Shannon Cross of Cross Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Shannon Cross of Cross Research.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Cathie, can you talk a bit about what you're seeing from a government standpoint in terms of impact from austerity or perhaps even more demand out of the government as they look to outsource more? And then I have a follow up.
componenttext: Cathie, can you talk a bit about what you're seeing from a government standpoint in terms of impact from austerity or perhaps even more demand out of the government as they look to outsource more? And then I have a follow up.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Shannon, public sector business was solid in some countries this quarter and a little bit tougher in some other countries like the U.K. It wasn't really a material driver of strength or weakness in the quarter. We did see strong signs in basically our U.S
componenttext:
Shannon, public sector business was solid in some countries this quarter and a little bit tougher in some other countries like the U.K. It wasn't really a material driver of strength or weakness in the quarter. We did see strong signs in basically our U.S. public sector business. And I think what's really important in this space plus in the commercial space is the economic value proposition of some of our products.
I think that that makes a huge difference, when you can show a customer whether it's public sector or otherwise that you've got a very strong return on the investments or you have a huge value proposition in a networking business, I think that will really help us in this area.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: If you look at our networking business in particular, we were very pleased, not just for the public sector customers but more broadly. When you've got a product like what we've got now between 3Com and ProCurve we have a really strong value proposition. T
componenttext:
If you look at our networking business in particular, we were very pleased, not just for the public sector customers but more broadly. When you've got a product like what we've got now between 3Com and ProCurve we have a really strong value proposition. The networking market has been one characterized by high prices, proprietary products and little choice.
And now that HP has got the offering we have, we're just seeing a very strong demand for the products. And we are able to offer our networking products at a very attractive price, and yet at the same time generate very attractive margins.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And then Cathie, if you can just talk a little bit about share repurchase. If I heard right during your commentary it's going to be sort of similar in terms of cash usage in fourth quarter. But I am just curious, given what's happened to the share price i
componenttext: And then Cathie, if you can just talk a little bit about share repurchase. If I heard right during your commentary it's going to be sort of similar in terms of cash usage in fourth quarter. But I am just curious, given what's happened to the share price if you are looking at possibly accelerating even more in terms of the shares you buy back or just in general. So what are your thoughts?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Shannon, in Q3 we accelerated our share buyback pretty significantly. We spent $2.6 billion in share repurchase in Q3, up from $1.8 billion in the previous quarter. And we do expect to continue to be active in our shares. And I think it's also important t
componenttext:
Shannon, in Q3 we accelerated our share buyback pretty significantly. We spent $2.6 billion in share repurchase in Q3, up from $1.8 billion in the previous quarter. And we do expect to continue to be active in our shares. And I think it's also important to note that our option overhang has come down very significantly and it now represents roughly 6% of the shares outstanding, which is about half of what it was three years ago.
The importance of that, of course, is that the cost of maintaining zero dilution and offsetting dilution from employee benefit plans has come down very significantly. And therefore, when you spend $2.6 billion in the quarter, it goes heavily to getting shares off the table. We do expect, as I mentioned in the my prepared remarks, that you should model about a 30 million share decline from Q3 to Q4, which is about what we saw from Q2 to Q3.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Craig of Bank of America-Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Craig of Bank of America-Merrill Lynch.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Cathie, just to start on the services business, you mentioned you thought margins were going to start to uptick next quarter. But can you maybe give us an outlook for when you think the revenue growth starts to accelerate, given how well you've done on th
componenttext:
Cathie, just to start on the services business, you mentioned you thought margins were going to start to uptick next quarter. But can you maybe give us an outlook for when you think the revenue growth starts to accelerate, given how well you've done on the bookings?
And then just with regards to the fourth quarter guidance overall, you've done a number of acquisitions and the business mix is changing. So how do you guys view normal seasonality now in the fourth quarter and your guidance relative to that?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the services, what we're working on, as I think Ann mentioned, is getting our cost structure right. And once you get your cost structure right, you have that opportunity to bid much more competitively. And we're starting to see that in the str
componenttext:
In terms of the services, what we're working on, as I think Ann mentioned, is getting our cost structure right. And once you get your cost structure right, you have that opportunity to bid much more competitively. And we're starting to see that in the strong signings and the pipeline.
So given those cost structure improvements coupled with the investments we have been making in sales coverage as well as innovative services offering, we expect to outgrow the market in the long term and be closer to the market. Well, we're at market now. We expect the market to uptick a bit. But we expect to be at market in 2011 as well. And we'll talk more about that at the security analyst meeting.
In terms of seasonality, from a revenue perspective, one of the big adjustments that you need to make on quarterly seasonality is the addition of the EDS to the portfolio. So a number of you are running around with models that say that the normal sequential increase in revenue from Q3 to Q4 is double digit. So when you layer in EDS, that significantly dampens that normal seasonality. So there is more in the range of 8.5 points.
When we put our guidance together, we basically looked at half-two over half-one. And if you look at it on that basis, we have roughly normal seasonality, half-two over half-one. We had a great start in Q3. We are of course, as our usual-self, prudent in Q4. And if we do better than assumptions that we've modeled, we'll have upside in revenue and EPS in Q4.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tony Sacconaghi of Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tony Sacconaghi of Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: I had two follow-up questions. I wanted to first push you on the share repurchase. You did $2.6 billion this quarter. Your stock price is obviously considerably lower as you enter Q4. And your option overhang it sounds like has not changed.Why wouldn't
componenttext:
I had two follow-up questions. I wanted to first push you on the share repurchase. You did $2.6 billion this quarter. Your stock price is obviously considerably lower as you enter Q4. And your option overhang it sounds like has not changed.
Why wouldn't you be looking to materially step up your share repurchases or invariably you're going to get more bang for your buck given the lower stock price? So why wouldn't we expect a greater decline in share count? And can you talk about how offshore or onshore cash may be a constraint in your ability to be more aggressive here?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Tony, let me address the second part of your question first. Whether offshore or onshore is not a constraint for us. The capacity that we have in the capital structure of our balance sheet is not a constraint at all. It doesn't matter where the cash is. W
componenttext:
Tony, let me address the second part of your question first. Whether offshore or onshore is not a constraint for us. The capacity that we have in the capital structure of our balance sheet is not a constraint at all. It doesn't matter where the cash is. We can either borrow or we have access to much of the cash offshore as it is. So that's not a constraint.
In terms of what we're actually doing share repurchase this quarter, we will announce it when we announce our fourth quarter earnings. We don't typically give guidance of what our share repurchase amount is going to be. We decided this quarter it was best to give you a modeling assumption to use about 30 million shares. But obviously we were active in Q3. We like the stock price in Q3. Q4 looks even more attractive.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And then I wanted to follow-up on the guidance. So you're guiding for about 6% sequential growth. You've done the EDS adjustments. It still gets me to something that's about 9% for average seasonality over the last six or so quarters.Can you comment on
componenttext:
And then I wanted to follow-up on the guidance. So you're guiding for about 6% sequential growth. You've done the EDS adjustments. It still gets me to something that's about 9% for average seasonality over the last six or so quarters.
Can you comment on what you expect currency to be sequentially? And again, I think if we were to look at normal seasonality just for EDS in the front half of the year, you are kind of in line. And so the discrepancy seems pretty significant. Do you have a discounted view of how strong consumer can be in the fourth quarter, and is that part of the gap?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: First, in terms of the currency that we are seeing from Q3 to Q4, because of the hedges that we have in place, there isn't much of a currency tailwind or headwind from Q3 to Q4, which might well be different than what you all are modeling, because you don
componenttext:
First, in terms of the currency that we are seeing from Q3 to Q4, because of the hedges that we have in place, there isn't much of a currency tailwind or headwind from Q3 to Q4, which might well be different than what you all are modeling, because you don't have a full understanding of the hedges that we have in place. That's the first thing.
And then in terms of the way we thought about Q4 was we really looked at the seasonality of the half-two over half-one, and we had a strong start to that half with Q3. And I don't think there is anything more to it than that.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Bill Fearnley of Janney Montgomery Scott.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Bill Fearnley of Janney Montgomery Scott.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: If I could address a question to V. J. in printing, it appears that the supply chain is fixed. And so with a strong hardware performance this quarter, you still came in at the high end of the15% to 17% range. So should we be thinking about IPG operating m
componenttext: If I could address a question to V. J. in printing, it appears that the supply chain is fixed. And so with a strong hardware performance this quarter, you still came in at the high end of the15% to 17% range. So should we be thinking about IPG operating margins in the 16% to 18% range, given the strong hardware performance?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me address that. We don't let V. J. talk about those things. Our guidance for this year is 15% to 17%, and we're not really changing that at this point. We will talk more about what our guidance is for 2011 at our security analyst meeting. Our goal is
componenttext: Let me address that. We don't let V. J. talk about those things. Our guidance for this year is 15% to 17%, and we're not really changing that at this point. We will talk more about what our guidance is for 2011 at our security analyst meeting. Our goal is to get as much growth as we can in good usage hardware unit and stay within our 15% to 17%.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And have you seen any effect of the expanded Canon relationship, any benefit there in the most recent quarter?
componenttext: And have you seen any effect of the expanded Canon relationship, any benefit there in the most recent quarter?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: We've started with the copier lineup. We like the lineup that we've got. We have really managed print services. We had a very good quarter for our total contract value for management services. And I think important part is we want to continue to invest an
componenttext: We've started with the copier lineup. We like the lineup that we've got. We have really managed print services. We had a very good quarter for our total contract value for management services. And I think important part is we want to continue to invest and innovate, because innovation is our bloodline. So we want to make sure that not only we place high usage units, but also continue to innovate.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Moskowitz of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Moskowitz of JPMorgan.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Two quick questions here. One, Cathie, how should we think about the offsets here in terms of PSG has driven a lot of your revenue upsides for HP over the past year-and-a-half or so, not all of it, but a good piece of it? And just the softening that we're
componenttext: Two quick questions here. One, Cathie, how should we think about the offsets here in terms of PSG has driven a lot of your revenue upsides for HP over the past year-and-a-half or so, not all of it, but a good piece of it? And just the softening that we're seeing out there in the consumer side, are there other pieces in the pipeline, whether it's IPG, you talked a little about services growth here forthcoming that can help bridge that gap of this PSG.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Really what we've seen, and I am sure you are aware, we've got both consumer and commercial solutions that drove our revenue in the third quarter to 11% growth. In the softer economy, what we saw was a more resilient consumer and a commercial side of the
componenttext:
Really what we've seen, and I am sure you are aware, we've got both consumer and commercial solutions that drove our revenue in the third quarter to 11% growth. In the softer economy, what we saw was a more resilient consumer and a commercial side of the business across the company that puts more of the brakes on spending. And now what we are seeing pick up faster is the commercial side of the business.
So we've seen improved growth there and good margins, and we saw also strong performance within the PC business, in the consumer desktop and in commercial and workstations particularly. That obviously helped offset some of the growth changes on the consumer side.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: And then I know the dust has not settled as far as the CEO departure. I just want to get your stance in terms of, in recent days have you established some sort of delta force, where you have maybe a tactical team that has to go out and really provide acco
componenttext: And then I know the dust has not settled as far as the CEO departure. I just want to get your stance in terms of, in recent days have you established some sort of delta force, where you have maybe a tactical team that has to go out and really provide account coverage for your platinum accounts, because I know the prior CEO definitely had a very aggressive customer-facing type of mantra in addition to cost cutting.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: If you look at our customer coverage, as you would expect, we've got account general managers on all of our top accounts. And we have sales rep coverage, which we've been increasing month-by-month throughout the year. And so from a pure account coverage p
componenttext:
If you look at our customer coverage, as you would expect, we've got account general managers on all of our top accounts. And we have sales rep coverage, which we've been increasing month-by-month throughout the year. And so from a pure account coverage perspective, now they're not going to notice a delta.
If you look at just one person, any one person, they solely are not going to be what drives the sales relationship, the customer relationship. My staff and I, the whole executive committee, have lots of customer relationships with our largest accounts. And we're making those calls and continuing to make those calls.
You talk about our top accounts, I'll put another plug in for our networking business; of our top 1,000 customers in the last 90 days, we've already had 300 of them sign up for these proof of concepts we're doing. So there is no wavering, there is no question, there's no issue with our top accounts.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010

componenttext: Cathie on the Industry Standard Server segment, granted the growth rate was pretty strong on a year-over-year basis, but the sequential growth rate was at the low end of historical patterns. How should we think about the puts and takes given the demand and the corporate purchasing was pretty strong?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm struggling a little here, because in fact our industry standard server growth was ahead of normal quarterly seasonality. So we continue to see good strength in industry standard server.
componenttext: I'm struggling a little here, because in fact our industry standard server growth was ahead of normal quarterly seasonality. So we continue to see good strength in industry standard server.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: I was looking at the historical patterns and I assume I might be looking at the wrong numbers there. Lastly, on the storage side, given Dell's acquisition of 3Par, do you see any significant competitive shifts over there? And people kind of look at cloud
componenttext: I was looking at the historical patterns and I assume I might be looking at the wrong numbers there. Lastly, on the storage side, given Dell's acquisition of 3Par, do you see any significant competitive shifts over there? And people kind of look at cloud computing, so do you think you have the full portfolio in that area?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: If we look at our storage business, we're executing against the strategy you'd seen us executing against. Now, if we look particularly at this quarter, we had an exceptionally strong quarter with our scale out ISCSI products. And that's the technology and
componenttext:
If we look at our storage business, we're executing against the strategy you'd seen us executing against. Now, if we look particularly at this quarter, we had an exceptionally strong quarter with our scale out ISCSI products. And that's the technology and product basis that we acquired with LeftHand. So we had triple-digit growth. So it's just a great quarter in customer reception there.
We've also been very pleased with our Ibrix acquisition, which gave us a file based storage offering. And then as well this quarter, we introduced our StoreOnce deduplication product as I mentioned earlier. And the customer reception to this has just been fantastic. So we feel good about all those things.
When you talk about applications and the cloud movement and the things happening there, the other thing that we announced this week which is very pertinent for that space is our acquisition of Fortify Software. And as customers are moving more and more applications to the cloud, they are even more intensely concerned about testing for the security associated with applications. And so that's a move that we made in that space that's very aligned with moving applications to the cloud and the whole security related to it.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Fidacaro of Susquehanna.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Fidacaro of Susquehanna.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Just on the supply side; grew 5% in the quarter. Could you talk a little bit about how the inventory looks there? Was there any points contributing to a channel fill? And I may have missed this, but how is the fiscal fourth quarter shaping up? Is that sor
componenttext: Just on the supply side; grew 5% in the quarter. Could you talk a little bit about how the inventory looks there? Was there any points contributing to a channel fill? And I may have missed this, but how is the fiscal fourth quarter shaping up? Is that sort of a mid-single-digit type growth again?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: I think the channel looks very satisfying, as Cathie mentioned. We are focused on making sure that we put the right units into place and get the right sell out. As far as the Q4 is concerned, we have continued to look at the mid-single-digit range.
componenttext: I think the channel looks very satisfying, as Cathie mentioned. We are focused on making sure that we put the right units into place and get the right sell out. As far as the Q4 is concerned, we have continued to look at the mid-single-digit range.

componenttext: And I think I should have said that we got the 8% constant currency growth without the benefit of any channel fill unlike some of our competition.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Aaron Rakers of Stifel Nicolaus.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions; the first one, I've heard you guys talk a couple of times now about the enterprise pull-through effect from your services business as you kind of migrate into the phase II of the EDS relationship or acquisition. Is there any way loo
componenttext: A couple of questions; the first one, I've heard you guys talk a couple of times now about the enterprise pull-through effect from your services business as you kind of migrate into the phase II of the EDS relationship or acquisition. Is there any way looking at the model how we can look at that or is there any ways of quantifying that pull-through effect that we can really start to see that show up in the HP model over the coming quarters. And then I do have a follow up.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: There are a couple of things associated with that. You heard both Cathie and I comment that our product pull-through was up 50% year-over-year, and we expected this increase to continue. You can think about it in two parts, as we solution the new deal, we
componenttext:
There are a couple of things associated with that. You heard both Cathie and I comment that our product pull-through was up 50% year-over-year, and we expected this increase to continue. You can think about it in two parts, as we solution the new deal, we have an opportunity to build HP technology into those solutions.
And then as customers get to upgrade points in the services contracts that we have with them, that's another opportunity for us to bring our technology into the solution. So it's both those areas.
Another data point that we have is, we know that in every client, when we look at the customers where we have a $50 million services relationship or larger, our share of wallet with the rest of HP's portfolio is higher in those clients than in the rest of our customer base. So those are all good points.
We'll have to think about how we can perhaps give you some view around how to model it, but you should be confident that a big part of our strategy is going to be to use our Services business to bring customers the best technology, and in most case we think that's HP.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Inventory build, obviously it looks like that that was less about strategic purchases in the quarter for you guys. Did you give any commentary of what you're seeing component wise in terms of the pricing environment as we look into the next couple of quar
componenttext: Inventory build, obviously it looks like that that was less about strategic purchases in the quarter for you guys. Did you give any commentary of what you're seeing component wise in terms of the pricing environment as we look into the next couple of quarters?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: On the component side, basically from Q2 to Q3, the component situation improved both availability, and pricing became much more stable. We still obviously have an increase year-on-year. In terms of gong into Q4, we expected to stay kind of relatively sta
componenttext: On the component side, basically from Q2 to Q3, the component situation improved both availability, and pricing became much more stable. We still obviously have an increase year-on-year. In terms of gong into Q4, we expected to stay kind of relatively stable. And obviously, expect the availability of supply to continue to be good enough.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010

componenttext: Just on the storage side, if you look at your revenues up 10% year-over-year, EBIT I think was actually down, some of the pure storage vendors are seeing substantially better year-over-year revenue growth. So my question was do you feel that you have all the right assets in the storage marketplace given you desire to expand the total addressable market for HP?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: If you look at the newer assets that we have in our portfolio, they're still relatively small. So from the overall impact to the growth rate, they don't have as a big an impact yet as they do with each successive quarter associated with it. You're going t
componenttext: If you look at the newer assets that we have in our portfolio, they're still relatively small. So from the overall impact to the growth rate, they don't have as a big an impact yet as they do with each successive quarter associated with it. You're going to see us in our storage business continue to be very focused on it and continue to invest in it. It's a critical part of our overall strategy to lead with converged infrastructure. Having a strong storage portfolio with valid servers and networking and management software is all part of the strategy we're driving.

componenttext: You don't think you'd like a high-end SAN offering or scale-out offering that you need to roundup the entire product. It's a matter of just growing what you have into more revenue numbers?

componenttext: If you look at our XP offering, we actually had a very strong quarter with our XP businesses this quarter. So we're comfortable with those results.
