componenttextpreview: In fact, we grew the XP business greater than 20% year-on-year this quarter.
componenttext: In fact, we grew the XP business greater than 20% year-on-year this quarter.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll actually wrap the questions up now and turn the final comments over to Cathie.
componenttext: We'll actually wrap the questions up now and turn the final comments over to Cathie.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Before I go into my final closing comments, I did want to introduce Steve Fieler. Steve Fieler is our new VP of IR, who you all will hopefully meet in the next 30 to 60 days. And I want to thank Jim Burns for a tremendously good job he did as the VP of IR
componenttext: Before I go into my final closing comments, I did want to introduce Steve Fieler. Steve Fieler is our new VP of IR, who you all will hopefully meet in the next 30 to 60 days. And I want to thank Jim Burns for a tremendously good job he did as the VP of IR. And by the way, he just slipped this piece of paper to me and said, "Make sure you say this," that he is really ready to go and support Ann as the Enterprise Business CFO. So thank you very much, Jim. Just to conclude. We have, and we are, a very strong company. Our broad-based results in Q3 clearly demonstrate our ability to execute across many dimensions in this company. We've got the right assets. We've got the right strategy and frankly, we've got the right people to execute the strategy. We have unique and sustainable competitive advantages that provide us the platform that we need to drive profitable growth. And these are the advantages, along with our ability to execute, that have allowed us to raise our full year outlook for this year. We are aggressively moving forward, and I'm confident in our ability to deliver results for our employees, our customers and you, our shareholders. And with that, I just want to thank you for your time today especially for those of you who had to stay late because of Dell announcing as well. Thank you.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-19-2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, this concludes our call for today. Thank you.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, this concludes our call for today. Thank you.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the fourth quarter 2010 Hewlett-Packard earnings conference call. My name is Michael and I will be your conference moderator for today's call. At this time, all participants are in a listen-only mode. We will
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the fourth quarter 2010 Hewlett-Packard earnings conference call. My name is Michael and I will be your conference moderator for today's call. At this time, all participants are in a listen-only mode. We will be facilitating a question-and-answer session towards the end of the conference. (Operator instructions) As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes.
I would now like to turn the presentation over to your host for today's call, Mr. Steve Fieler, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please proceed.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. Welcome to our fourth quarter earnings conference call with Leo Apotheker, HP’s CEO and Cathie Lesjak, HP’s Chief Financial officer. Also joining us are Todd Bradley, Executive Vice President, for the Personal Systems Group; Ann Liverm
componenttext:
Good afternoon. Welcome to our fourth quarter earnings conference call with Leo Apotheker, HP’s CEO and Cathie Lesjak, HP’s Chief Financial officer. Also joining us are Todd Bradley, Executive Vice President, for the Personal Systems Group; Ann Livermore, Executive Vice President of the HP Enterprise Business; and Vyomesh Joshi, Executive Vice President of the Imaging and Printing Group.
This call is being webcast. A replay of the webcast will be available shortly after the call for approximately one year.
Some information provided during this call may include forward-looking statements that are based on certain assumptions and are subject to a number of risks and uncertainties and actual future results may vary materially. Please refer to the risks described in HP's SEC reports, including our most recent Form 10-Q. The financial information discussed in connection with this call, including tax-related items, reflects estimates based on information available at this time and could differ materially from the amounts ultimately reported in HP's 2010 Form 10-K.
Earnings, operating margins, and similar items at the Company level are sometimes expressed on a non-GAAP basis and have been adjusted to exclude certain items, including amortization of purchased intangibles, restructuring charges, and acquisition-related charges. The comparable GAAP financial information and a reconciliation of non-GAAP amounts to GAAP are included in the tables in the slide presentation accompanying today's earnings release, both of which are available on the HP Investor Relations' webpage at www.hp.com.
I'll now turn the call over to Leo.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome to our fourth quarter earnings calls and thank you for joining us today. Since the last time we spoke, I have been meeting with our customers and partners as well as thousands of employees around the world. I joked on today of the announcement tha
componenttext:
Welcome to our fourth quarter earnings calls and thank you for joining us today. Since the last time we spoke, I have been meeting with our customers and partners as well as thousands of employees around the world. I joked on today of the announcement that I might set world record for travel and I think I might have actually done it. I have been listening, I have been learning and I have been immersing this over the business and today I'm even more excited and honored to be HP CEO.
HP is a Company with great momentum incredibly committed in terms of people, deep customer relationships and strong core businesses. I'm confident in our future and energized about the opportunity that lies ahead. When I look at our Q4 results, what's clear is that HP is winning in the market and we have an impressive ability to execute. I'm proud of our leadership team and our people for their continued focus doing what has been extraordinary time for the Company.
We finished our fiscal year with $126 billion in revenues. It's a 10% year-over-year increase or an incremental $11.5 billion of growth. We grew nearly $1 billion per month last year. During the same time, we expanded our non-GAAP operating profit faster than revenue, up 14% year-over-year and our non-GAAP EPS grew even faster at 19% for the full year. It is evidence of our strong operating leverage, our leadership positions, our ability to grow in higher margin categories and our strong balance sheet. We are carrying this momentum into FY'11.We have the ability to drive continued growth and at the same time, I remain committed to driving operational efficiencies into the years ahead. I'm confident in our updated FY'11 outlook, which Cathie will share with you in a moment.
Before Cathie provides more financial detail, however, I would like to share some of my initial observations about HP, our potential, and also errors where we need to do things better. Now bear in mind, these are just my initial thoughts. I have been on the job for just about three weeks now and I still have good amount of listening and data gathering to do. I intend to provide the more robust perspective in the next few months.
Well, now I will share three observations; one about customers, the second is about our employees, and third about our technologies. I have received great feedback from our customers thus far. They are asking for solution partner who have hardware and software technology, and business challenges. They want to access to information instantly no matter where they are and they want choice not proprietary logins.
The great majority are telling me that they want to do more business with HP. They are like our openness, our price performance, our industry-leading technologies, and our focus on manageability and security.
Look at ISS share gains in revenue which was up 32% year-over-year. ProCurve Networking, another good example, was up 50% organically year-over-year. PSG continues to be the worldwide leader in PCs. Our enterprise customers want the ability to work in hybrid environments both cloud and traditional, and this is HP's long-term opportunity and leverage.
What they are mostly hearing that we need to make it easier for customers to work with HP. We need to have the right coverage model that meets their needs and we must be even more focused on bringing our customers product and solutions that deliver the promise of Instant-On [ph] across the consumer, SMB and enterprise segments.
I have also enjoyed talking with our employees all over the world. They are very focused on our customers and growing our business. They have terrific ideas and also know how to derive operation efficiency. We welcome new employees from 3PAR outside 45 in SATA VIA [ph] in the fourth quarter and I am excited about these additions and integrations as starting of well.
HP employees are highly competitive group who wants to win. They also want to be rewarded for their performance. This is consistent across the globe. I believe in the performance-driven culture and our employees have been performing. Therefore, I am pleased that we will be reinstituting salary increases in FY '11 as part of our normal annual review process. It's well deserve.
Also, we are creating more sustainable collaborative and productive workspaces for all employees. As part of this ongoing workspace initiative, we (inaudible) our global headquarters in Palo Alto and we just completed the sale of our Cupertino campus and with the consolidated HP Cupertino's side into Palo Alto over the next three years.
Now let me switch to technology. As Cathie described to you at the Securities Analyst Meeting in September, we have been increasing our investment in R&D. In the fourth quarter, R&D was up more than revenue growth both year-over-year and sequentially. We should expect this trend to continue. We have a strong product portfolio with innovation across the Company. In the fourth quarter, we began shipping our Superdome 2 and our BCS business was up 10%. IPG achieved another strong quarter including share gains in both laser and ink and we continue to innovate around ePrint and web-connected printers. I am very excited about the opportunity available to us to shape the planet at mobile instant arm platform.
Moving forward, I am excited to spend more time digging into our technology. We have so much opportunity, unique opportunity as a Company and it’s not simply about spending in R&D, rather it’s about driving more leverage from our existing portfolio and resources to crease HP Solutions. It is about adding more agility to our scale and accelerating our innovation cycles.
We are in a unique position to drive better, more consistent and unified user experiences across our portfolio like with our converse infrastructure offerings and we can leverage even more technologies to create integrated value added solutions in addition to our point products. Just as we have our customers knock down their technologies titles, we have the opportunity to knock down a few of our own.
HP has already been moving in this direction but we can do more. We need to enhance our software IP across the Company to create more differentiation with our products this includes strengthening our core software business segment as well as adding value added IP and services that cut across all segments.
As an example HP has the leading software, a unique IP called Metavante, an interchange to administer health plans and pose as (inaudible) healthcare organizations. This is an HP platform that leverages software IP and infrastructure along with value added services to provide the fully integrated vertical solution. To-date HP’s processes over a billion claims in U.S. annually where about one in every four themes. HP now runs Medicaid in 22 states. We're improving quality of care and reducing operational costs for our healthcare customers and ultimately serving both their technology and business challenges together.
In the next weeks and months ahead, I will continue engaging with our customers, partners, employees, senior leaders and investors while I still have more listening to do as you think already very evident to me. HP is a strong company. We have a significant opportunity in front of us and we will continue to lead the market presence and create value for our customers and shareholders.
I'll now hand the call over to Cathie.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank, Leo. Hewlett-Packard delivered strong balance growth in the fourth quarter across all regions and market segments. In Q4, we added $2.5 billion of new revenue, expanded gross margins and operating margins and grew earnings per share by 17% year-on-
componenttext:
Thank, Leo. Hewlett-Packard delivered strong balance growth in the fourth quarter across all regions and market segments. In Q4, we added $2.5 billion of new revenue, expanded gross margins and operating margins and grew earnings per share by 17% year-on-year. We continue to execute our strategy moving up the stack and increasing our mix of higher margin businesses to drive sustainable gross margin improvement.
In Q4, we saw a strong growth in margin accretive solutions such as Virtual Connect and Blade System Matrix as well as the contribution from strategic acquisitions such as 3Com. These benefits combined with disciplined pricing and promotion activity drove gross margin expansion of 110 basis points versus the prior year to 24.8%.
We are investing for growth and augmenting our global sales force to improve the coverage of our $1.6 trillion addressable market. Our solution portfolio and technology offerings are strong and we're encouraged by the initial results of our enterprise sales force deployment. Looking into the details of the quarter, revenue for the fourth quarter totaled $33.3 billion, up 8% from the prior year or 9% adjusting for currency.
We continue to see momentum in the commercial sectors led by strength in converged infrastructure, managed print services, and commercial printers and PCs.
We posted solid double digit revenue growth across our hardware businesses with enterprise server and storage growing 25% and ProCurve networking up 50%. Commercial printer hardware and PSG commercial revenue grew 22% and 20%, respectively. Additionally in Services, our book-to-bill ratio for the trailing 12-month remained comfortably greater than one.
Looking at revenue by geography, we had balanced performance with revenues in the Americas and EMEA increasing 10% and 6%, respectively. In Asia-Pacific, revenue grew 8% with strong growth across the region, partially offset by some ongoing HP challenges in the China PC business. Excluding China, Asia Pacific achieved double-digit revenue growth.
Turning to the expense side, operating expenses increased to $4.2 billion as we accelerated investments to drive long-term growth, including increases in R&D and expansion of our sales force. We are strengthening R&D both through incremental investments and the addition of strong technical talent from the acquisitions that we made in fiscal 2010.
Non-GAAP operating income increased 10% year-on-year to $4 billion as growth margin expansion more than offset the incremental investments in sales and R&D. Fourth quarter non-GAAP net income improved to $3.1 billion and non-GAAP diluted earnings per share increased 17% to $1.33.
Looking at the full year, we delivered revenue of $126 billion, non-GAAP operating income of $14.4 billion or 11.4% of revenue, and grew non-GAAP earnings per share by 19% to $4.58.
As Leo mentioned, HP is focused on creating value for our customers. In the Enterprise business this means driving our vision by delivering converged infrastructure, modernizing application, picturing the enterprise and managing information. This quarter demonstrates another proof point that HP is winning.
The enterprise storage and server business produced record revenue of $5.3 billion in the quarter, up 25% year-over-year with balanced double-digit growth across each business unit and every region. Operating profit for the business was up 52% on a year-over-year basis with $730 million with operating margin of 13.9%, an increase of 250 basis points from the prior year demonstrating the operating leverage in the model.
Our Industry Standard Server business achieved the number one market share position in all three regions with growth of 32% and ESS Blades far outpaced the market with 51% growth year-over-year.
Within the Business critical systems group, we successful launch the integrity Superdome 2 as the flagship solution of the mission critical converged infrastructure. Superdome 2 delivers best-in-class system level performance and scalability, while improving resiliency more than four times over the original Superdome.
Business critical systems revenue grew 10% year-over-year with strong growth in the telecom sector in the Americas and more balanced growth across verticals in other regions.
In Storage, revenue increased 14% from the prior year with balanced growth across our broad portfolio. We are investing in the most attractive high growth segment and our strategy is working.
In Q4, we delivered triple-digit growth in our scale-out iSCSI product. Our enterprise NAS and our StoreOnce data de-duplication technology. We are also over very pleased with the traction and buzz around the 3PAR acquisition which closed on September 27. We are already seeing accelerating interest in these products from our existing and new customers and expect to extend three parts of routes to market by leveraging HP’s broad channel and enterprise sales force.
HP Networking, which is reported in the Corporate Investment continues to build on its worldwide momentum while executing ahead of plan. Revenue in HP Networking grew 227% with ProCurve revenues up 50%. A tipping point security portfolio also delivered strong growth. In the Americas region, historically one of the most competitive markets HP ProCurve more than doubled. We see strong demand for our networking solutions as our value proposition of better performance, improved security, simple pain of glass manageability and lower cost of ownership is resonating with our customers.
Enterprise customers continue to demonstrate interest in our Networking product portfolio with over 400 of HP’s top global accounts enrolling in the HP Networking proof-of-concept program which we closed 3Com in April. We had a good quarter in state and local government accounts as well as new wins with the BMW Group and Underwriters Laboratories.
Services delivered revenue of $9 billion, up slightly from the prior year. Infrastructure technology outsourcing, application services and technology services revenues each grew roughly 1%. Outsourcing saw strength in the U.S. public sector with renewals and new Medicaid business. Business processing outsourcing was down 11% including a 7% negative impact due to the divestiture of accelerate HRO.
Our pipeline of Enterprise Services opportunities remains robust and we are actively investing in the field to build out our addressable market coverage.
We continue to see healthy HP product pull-through in our Enterprise Service accounts and we expect this trend to continue.
Services segment operating profit in the quarter increased to $1.5 billion or 16.7% of revenue, up 50 basis points from the prior year, driven by improvements in service delivery. For the full year, Services delivered $5.6 billion in operating profit and expanded operating margins by 160 basis points even as we continued to invest in sales coverage, transformation and on boarding new deals.
HP Software revenue was $974 million, up 1% compared with the prior year. Business Technology Optimization revenue increased 4% and Other Software revenue declined 6%. We are excited about expanding our security presence with the recent acquisitions of Fortify and ArcSight in the quarter. The Software business expanded its operating margins by 120 basis points year-over-year. Operating profit was $247 million or 25.4% of revenue, up from $234 million or 24.2% of revenue in the prior year period.
Turning to Personal Systems. PSG revenue increased 4% from the prior year to $10.3 billion with total unit shipments growing 2%. Segment operating profit totaled $568 million or 5.5% of revenue, up 80 basis points year-over-year as PSG benefitted from favorable component pricing and disciplined pricing and promotion programs.
The commercial refresh continues. In SMB, we are launching new call centers internationally, building on the success we have seen with the call centers in the U.S. We maintained our market leadership position in commercial PCs and once again expanded our share in the U.S. enterprise segment by winning new accounts from competitors and investing in channel program. As a result, commercial client revenue grew 20%, workstations had another strong quarter with 55% growth, and commercial desktop revenue was up 23% year-over-year.
Total notebook revenue was down 3% reflecting softness in consumer notebooks. The consumer weakness was predominantly in low-end notebooks and largely impacted by our performance in China. The issues in China are well within HP's control and we are addressing them.
Our current focus is on rebuilding our brand and channel relationship, so that HP can regain this share loss as a result of late in quality issues this past spring. We spoke to you at our September Analyst meeting about our PC efforts in Brazil and I'm pleased to report that HP has taken the number one revenue share positions in Brazil.
Moving on to Palm which is reported in corporate investments. We continue to invest in the Palm assets, including the webOS in a variety of connected mobile devices. This quarter we released the webOS 2.0 and introduced the Palm Pre 2 smartphone.
Imaging and Printing had a strong quarter. Revenue grew 8% to $7 million fueled by year-over-year hardware revenue growth of 16% and supplies revenue growth of 6%. Segment operating profit totaled $1.2 billion or 17.4% of revenue. Total printer unit shipments increased 14% and regained market share across all printing categories with particular strength in higher usage segments.
Commercial printer units increased to 43% with multifunction printer units up 83%. Business ink and wireless printer units were up 22% and 53%, respectively. In addition, we shipped almost two million web-connected printers in the quarter.
We continue to innovate across our portfolio. In September, we announced Cloud Print for businesses using HP printer as well as new software capabilities for enterprise printing. In our hardware portfolio, we introduced new products in our Inkjet, LaserJet and Designjet categories.
Finally, we are delivering on our growth initiatives and retail publishing and manage print services. During fiscal 2010, we more than doubled our retail publishing installed base and delivered very significant growth in managed print services signing.
HP Financial Services continues to delivery strong consistent results. In the fourth quarter, financing revenue grew 11% to $809 million, financing volume increased 11% and net portfolio assets increased to 14%. Operating profit of $73 million compares to $66 million in the prior year. Return on equity for the fiscal year was 15%.
Now on to the balance sheet and cash flow. Our balance sheet remains strong. We closed the quarter with total gross cash of $11 billion. Our fourth quarter cash conversion cycle was 21 days up seven days from a year ago with day sales outstanding up two days, inventories flat and days payable down five days.
Channel inventories in each business are in good shape. TSG channel inventory is down from the prior quarter in line with our expectations. We generated operating cash flow of $3.2 billion and free cash flow of $2.2 billion.
During the fourth quarter, we returned $4 billion to shareholders through share repurchases and reduced our weighted average share outstanding by 79 million shares sequentially. At the end of the quarter we had roughly $10.9 billion remaining in our current share repurchase authorization.
Finally, we paid dividend totaling a $181 million. For the full year, we generated $11.9 billion in operating cash flow, $8.4 billion in free cash flow and returned $11 billion to shareholder through share repurchases and dividends.
Before I discuss the outlook, I wanted to remind that we expect to pay a cash bonus based on our fiscal 2010 performance, which will impact Q1 cash flow.
Now, a few comments on our outlook for the first quarter and full year fiscal '11. We expect Q1 fiscal 2011 revenue to be $32.8 billion to $33 billion. For the full year, we now expect revenue of $132 billion to $133.5 billion.
Regarding earnings, there are few variables to keep in mind. First, we will continue to fund investments to drive long-term growth and second, we expect OI&E expense of about $0.05 per share as a result of increased debt and more normalized foreign exchange currency losses.
We expect a tax rate of 22% and a more modest decline in weighted average shares outstanding than we had from Q3 to Q4. For the full year, we now expect weighted average diluted share count to be approximately 2.25 billion shares.
Thus on an operational basis, we expect first quarter earnings per share to be in the range of $1.24 to $1.26. In addition, in Q1 we expect to realize a one-time gain of approximately $0.04 per share primarily related to the disposition of real estate.
As a result, including this one-time $0.04 gain, we expect total first quarter EPS to be $1.28 to $1.30. For the full year, we are raising our earnings outlook and now expect non-GAAP EPS of $5.16 to $5.26 including the one-time $0.04 gain representing growth of approximately 13% to 15% to the fiscal year.
In summary, we feel good about our broad based performance in Q4 and for the year, we achieved double-digit growth in revenue, gross profit, operating profit and earnings per share as well as demonstrated the operating leverage in the model.
As a Company, we are executing on the plans we have laid out and delivering on our commitments to customers, partners, employees and investors. We are effectively balancing our growth, investments and efficiency initiative. We are well-positioned in the market and our full year outlook reflects our strength and ability to execute.
With that, we will now open the call for your questions.

componenttext: One for Leo and one for Cathie, if I could. Leo, first of all, you mentioned in your initial discussion the need to enhance HP Software IP position and I was just wondering if you had any initial thoughts on whether that could be accomplished organically or through a string of pearls or smaller acquisitions or whether HP needs to think about something more transformative there?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, that’s a very interest question. It's a bit early for me to give you a precise answer. What I can say at this moment in time is that if you want to strengthen our software capabilities, both at a business and also at a plus HP capability to add mo
componenttext: Well, that’s a very interest question. It's a bit early for me to give you a precise answer. What I can say at this moment in time is that if you want to strengthen our software capabilities, both at a business and also at a plus HP capability to add more value to the various activities that we undertake. We have many options available to us. We can do some of it organically, some of it non-organically and you'll easily understand that we won't comment on any M&A activity during this call.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Then Cathie, I was hoping you could comment on channel inventories, especially on supplies where it sounds like there were some price increases in Europe at the beginning of the quarter. I know typically you gave channel partners advance notice of these t
componenttext: Then Cathie, I was hoping you could comment on channel inventories, especially on supplies where it sounds like there were some price increases in Europe at the beginning of the quarter. I know typically you gave channel partners advance notice of these types of price increases. I was wondering if there was any inventory increase in supplies as a result of that.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: It must be Thanksgiving since we're giving you an opportunity to ask a second question. But in terms of channel inventories, we actually exited Q4 with channel inventories in really good shape. So there are no concerns from our perspective on the Channel
componenttext: It must be Thanksgiving since we're giving you an opportunity to ask a second question. But in terms of channel inventories, we actually exited Q4 with channel inventories in really good shape. So there are no concerns from our perspective on the Channel Inventory positions.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Ben Reitzes with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Ben Reitzes with Barclays Capital.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask Leo and the team about the environment and what you're seeing, in general, if you take your guidance lower share count could arguably account for more than half of the raise for the year. Obviously, if you put some of those sequential, it
componenttext: I wanted to ask Leo and the team about the environment and what you're seeing, in general, if you take your guidance lower share count could arguably account for more than half of the raise for the year. Obviously, if you put some of those sequential, it looks conservative on the revenue guidance in the first quarter. I was wondering, if you view this guidance as conservative and if you could talk a little bit more about, what you're seeing in the marketplace perhaps from the economic side, particularly in Europe?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: So, Ben, why don't I start with macro first. Since, I think that's underlying a lot of your number of questions in that one. Basically, from a macro perspective, what we saw was good balance performance across our regions. So, on a constant currency basis
componenttext: So, Ben, why don't I start with macro first. Since, I think that's underlying a lot of your number of questions in that one. Basically, from a macro perspective, what we saw was good balance performance across our regions. So, on a constant currency basis, we saw America's grow 9.5%, EMEA was up 11%, and excluding Japan, APJ grew double digits year-on-year. We also saw accelerated growth in emerging markets including Brazil, Russia and India. So that’s kind of a macro environment that we saw and then in terms of guidance for revenue and I will talk specifically about Q1, I think it's important to note A, for the year that we raised the midpoint of our revenue guidance and that the guidance now in Q1 shows revenue growth of 5% to 6% year-on-year, and you know us. We tend to be prudent and this quarter I think there are two good reasons for that. The first one is that we did see in Q4 uneven consumer performance across our geographies and our product categories. So that’s one element of prudent and then the other element is just that we are calling for a more modest increase in revenue in Industry Standard Service since we had seen significantly better than kind of normal seasonal growth in Industry Standard Servers for the past few quarters and so that kind of leads us to obviously the guidance that we have provided for Q1 revenue.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Keith Bachman with Bank of Montreal.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Keith Bachman with Bank of Montreal.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I want to see Cathie if you could talk a little bit about the context of your FY '11 guidance and specifically, you mentioned a number of times in your prepared remarks that you are increasing R&D and so as we think about it, should we assume that the gro
componenttext: I want to see Cathie if you could talk a little bit about the context of your FY '11 guidance and specifically, you mentioned a number of times in your prepared remarks that you are increasing R&D and so as we think about it, should we assume that the gross margins stay at or even go up from these levels as you increase OpEx or if you could just add a little color how we should be thinking about the FY tensions between growing OpEx versus meeting the expectations that you just laid out?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we talked a lot at the Security Analyst Meeting about the fact that our revenue mix and the growth that we see is in kind of more margin accretive category and then if you add in that the acquisitions that we have done as well, we do think that th
componenttext: Yes. So we talked a lot at the Security Analyst Meeting about the fact that our revenue mix and the growth that we see is in kind of more margin accretive category and then if you add in that the acquisitions that we have done as well, we do think that there is good upward pressure on gross margins. Of course, you didn't want to look seasonally at what normally would happen from Q4 to Q1 and then note that in Q1 it's typically our lowest gross margin quarter in the year.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Toni Sacconaghi, Jr. with Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Toni Sacconaghi, Jr. with Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I know you talked about R&D expense increasing and the rationale behind it, but your SG&A expense was up almost 17% and I think it was the first time more than seven years OpEx actually grew faster than revenue. Are you front-loading OpEx at all, because
componenttext: I know you talked about R&D expense increasing and the rationale behind it, but your SG&A expense was up almost 17% and I think it was the first time more than seven years OpEx actually grew faster than revenue. Are you front-loading OpEx at all, because my observation is, yes, you spent more on OpEx and you got higher gross margins? But if you look at operating margin, year-over-year your improvement in Q4 was actually the lowest it was in any quarter in 2010. So, if the notion is we are going to invest to get higher gross margins and ultimately that will translate into better operating margins, we actually didn’t really see it this quarter. Sorry for the long-winded backdrop. I guess the question is, how do we think about OpEx growth relative to revenues growth and was there any frontloading this quarter and if not, how do we rationalize that sensible trade-off you are making.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Toni I am quite sure I know what you mean by frontloading, but at the security analyst meeting what we said was that both R&D and sales expense would grow faster than revenues and that happened this quarter and we expect to have that be the case for all o
componenttext: Toni I am quite sure I know what you mean by frontloading, but at the security analyst meeting what we said was that both R&D and sales expense would grow faster than revenues and that happened this quarter and we expect to have that be the case for all of fiscal '11 and it is basically being funded by expanding gross margins in our business and we've talked about where the growth is happening and the acquisitions that we have made that are in more margin accretive category.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me be add a couple of comments to what Cathie has said. Let me be very clear about it. First of all, there is always an opportunity to drive increased productivity and in particular the leverage or scale and you can rest assure that we will never stop
componenttext: Let me be add a couple of comments to what Cathie has said. Let me be very clear about it. First of all, there is always an opportunity to drive increased productivity and in particular the leverage or scale and you can rest assure that we will never stop driving more efficiency and they are from very strong problems in place then it could happen, be it in the supply chain our services business and we're all committed and I'm particular committed to continue our focus on operational efficiencies. However, you need to invest to create sustainable operating leverage. We need to do this as continuing basis as well and we will use some of the savings as we generate some of our efficiency initiatives to continue investing it to more R&D and into more credit. We are also investing a little bit into our people all of this in order to ensure and that we have a strong business going forward.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, I need to correct something that I said. I apologize. I misspoke. When I talked about the macro environment and I talked about APJ growing double-digits in constant currency; I inadvertently said excluding Japan when in fact it's excluding China
componenttext: Actually, I need to correct something that I said. I apologize. I misspoke. When I talked about the macro environment and I talked about APJ growing double-digits in constant currency; I inadvertently said excluding Japan when in fact it's excluding China is what I intended to say and I apologize.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010

Is it possible to give us a rough quantification of that? It seems somewhat one-time in nature so let’s speak even though hopefully it'll happen every year for you guys but just wondering how much of an impact it's having next quarter.

componenttextpreview: Scott, it has not been one-time in nature. I think we have paid a comparable bonus each of the last, I want to say for years, but to do remotely possible, it was only three, but it's not materially different than what we've been seeing.
componenttext: Scott, it has not been one-time in nature. I think we have paid a comparable bonus each of the last, I want to say for years, but to do remotely possible, it was only three, but it's not materially different than what we've been seeing.

componenttext: Your next question comes from Katy Huberty with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Cathie, you talked about the reason for perhaps conservative revenue guidance in the first quarter which is more or less in line with consensus. In that context as well as some comments from peers around the public sector, can you talk about what gave you
componenttext: Cathie, you talked about the reason for perhaps conservative revenue guidance in the first quarter which is more or less in line with consensus. In that context as well as some comments from peers around the public sector, can you talk about what gave you the confidence to raise the full year 2011 revenue forecast versus the more conservative view next quarter?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. So, we actually basically raised the midpoint of the fiscal '11 guidance by basically compressing the range a bit and the confidence that we have is that we are performing very well. You saw it in Q4 and that gives us the confidence that we can make
componenttext: Yes. So, we actually basically raised the midpoint of the fiscal '11 guidance by basically compressing the range a bit and the confidence that we have is that we are performing very well. You saw it in Q4 and that gives us the confidence that we can make the range that we gave had the Security Analyst meeting but truncating off the bottom end.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Brian Alexander with Raymond James.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Brian Alexander with Raymond James.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you just comment a little bit more on the networking business? Obviously, it's a big opportunity for you guys. To what extent if you begun using the pricing the lever a little bit more to gain share, I think you previously said Cathie that 3Com's op
componenttext: Could you just comment a little bit more on the networking business? Obviously, it's a big opportunity for you guys. To what extent if you begun using the pricing the lever a little bit more to gain share, I think you previously said Cathie that 3Com's operating margins have drifted higher since you acquired them but at what point do you accelerate the share gain via pricing given the flexibility you have in the model?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think I also mentioned at that conference that not only 3Com’s margins shifted higher but so had Poker and that continues to be the case and I’ll let Ann comment more on the Networking business.
componenttext: I think I also mentioned at that conference that not only 3Com’s margins shifted higher but so had Poker and that continues to be the case and I’ll let Ann comment more on the Networking business.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah, in fact, we have seen networking as the great opportunity to simultaneously grow revenue, expand margins. If you look at the quarters we have been doing all three at one. In fact, to your point about the pricing, we have seen both revenue and margin
componenttext: Yeah, in fact, we have seen networking as the great opportunity to simultaneously grow revenue, expand margins. If you look at the quarters we have been doing all three at one. In fact, to your point about the pricing, we have seen both revenue and margin see ahead of plan and what we are seeing with 3Com is as Cathie said we are certainly pleased with the integration and for the first two quarters that has been part of HP the revenue for 3Com has been ahead of plan as well. We look broadly at our networking capability and Virtual Connect was up 50% and Broker [ph] was up 50% to what we are really seeing is we just got a value proposition that’s very attractive to customers. This is a marketplace where over the last few years, the marketplace was characterize by high prices, proprietary technologies and just flat out not enough competition and what HP has been able to bring to the market is something that customers just flat out really like. They like the fact that it's a new open architecture. They like the fact we are using industry standards. They like the fact that we have single management console which makes the cost of operations lower. They like the fact that our products have better energy efficiency and on top of all that we can price and still make great margins that our significant better value for them. We are just very pleased that the market acceptance and reaction that we’re seeing.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Aaron Rakers with Stifel Nicolaus.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Aaron Rakers with Stifel Nicolaus.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Question goes back to the gross margin line. I think on average over the past few years I think your sequential change in your gross margin going into the January quarter has been down about 30 to 40 basis points sequentially. Given the guidance you’ve
componenttext: Question goes back to the gross margin line. I think on average over the past few years I think your sequential change in your gross margin going into the January quarter has been down about 30 to 40 basis points sequentially. Given the guidance you’ve given, is there anything that in the model that changes that historical type of sequential trend and then on top of that can you help us bridge what was driving the gross margin between mix shift this last quarter versus obviously a more favorable component pricing environment?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I will take the last question first. Basically, the 110 basis point expansion in gross margin was from strength in networking as well as in the Enterprise Server and Storage, so that kind of the mix elements there. Then from a rate perspective the commodi
componenttext: I will take the last question first. Basically, the 110 basis point expansion in gross margin was from strength in networking as well as in the Enterprise Server and Storage, so that kind of the mix elements there. Then from a rate perspective the commodity pricing environment clearly benefitted PSG and then we had good service delivery efficiencies on the services side and combined that's really what drove the 110 basis point and improvement in gross margins and I would say in terms of the sequential kind of impact on the gross margins that we would be looking at kind of typical normal seasonality in from Q4 to Q1 and so I wouldn't model anything significantly differently than that.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Maynard Um with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Maynard Um with UBS.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Leo, can you talk about your comment about customers wanting choice and not vendor lock-in? Obviously, some of your competitors are driving vertically integrated stack solutions and certainly HP has a lot of those pieces within the stack and can you offer
componenttext: Leo, can you talk about your comment about customers wanting choice and not vendor lock-in? Obviously, some of your competitors are driving vertically integrated stack solutions and certainly HP has a lot of those pieces within the stack and can you offer this one-stop shopping for customers? Can you just may be expand on your comments there because in your comments that you want to own more of the software IP and assets presumably, you can pull along more hardware sales and make it more like a vertically integrated sac, but it sounds like that's not necessarily what your customers want, can you just help us understand the nuances there and what the plans are on expanding your software IP, is that a function of R&D as well?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, that's a number of questions posing, well, let me try to give you a bit of a summary answer on all of it. You're right in your analysis. What you have to recognize is that the customers have different use, have different points in their evolution. T
componenttext: Well, that's a number of questions posing, well, let me try to give you a bit of a summary answer on all of it. You're right in your analysis. What you have to recognize is that the customers have different use, have different points in their evolution. There is a very exciting thing happening out there, which is a trends towards cloud and customers want to get into the clouds depending on where they are coming from either in one shop or in gradual sets, they want to use public cloud or private cloud or they even want to stay in a hybrid environment. We are very well positioned to serve all of these demands from the market at different plus points and with various technologies. Customers don't want to get locked into a particular type of a standard, so we have been trying over many years to provide customers with open systems with industry standards and the success that we can see in our Converged Infrastructure has driven among others to closely provide openness [ph] to our customer. That doesn't mean that they cannot provide integrated solutions that contains also some of our own IP software because we believe that bundling it together and providing it as a solution in not an distinct and discrete products will give customers a higher value set. There are many examples that we could share and to give you one or two of them so that you get a better idea of what I'm trying to talk about.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: As Leo was just saying our strategy is quite different than some of our competitors because our strategy is actually to give customers choice, when you look at the integrated appliances that are on the market today, that's just one segment of the overall
componenttext: As Leo was just saying our strategy is quite different than some of our competitors because our strategy is actually to give customers choice, when you look at the integrated appliances that are on the market today, that's just one segment of the overall server market. What you'll see is that HP actually offers these integrated appliances, so we offer it with lots of different vendors. We offer these appliances with SAP, with Microsoft, with Oracle, and you'll see us offer these integrated tuned appliances with lots of different software vendors. Our view on this is that, when you are like HP and you've got the number one market share like x86 servers, then we have a 38% unit share, and then you've got the power of the converged infrastructure solutions we have across networking, and storage, and servers, and power, and cooling. Then what you can do is, you can help a customer transform their data center and at the same time, doing that without locking them into one proprietary set. So we're pleased with the positioning that we have here in the market.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: So, let me just start by confirming that consumer revenue does represent roughly 25% of our total revenue. Obviously, we've got pretty diverse portfolio, which serves us well when there are market shares, so we don't get impacted by quite as much as other
componenttext: So, let me just start by confirming that consumer revenue does represent roughly 25% of our total revenue. Obviously, we've got pretty diverse portfolio, which serves us well when there are market shares, so we don't get impacted by quite as much as other companies that are more concentrated. In Q4, we did see uneven consumer performance across our geographies and our product segments, and I think maybe I'll ask Todd to briefly talk about the PCs.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Cathie. I think the part of the first point is portfolio, our PC portfolio is diversified now across multiple consumer and commercial solutions and as the global economy slowly recovers, consumer’s PC purchases have remained somewhat soft while
componenttext: Thanks, Cathie. I think the part of the first point is portfolio, our PC portfolio is diversified now across multiple consumer and commercial solutions and as the global economy slowly recovers, consumer’s PC purchases have remained somewhat soft while business demand shows growing strength and I think more company have been ever a refreshing out of the older technologies. In the quarter, we saw very uneven consumer PC performance across our geographies. We saw EMEA with somewhat modest growth on a constant currency basis. In the U.S. consumers are somewhat cautious about spending and our increasingly deal-driven and the challenge is in Asia-Pacific, really look like the China which we’re fixing.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: In China space, specifically we're really focused on rebuilding our brand and our channel as well obviously our position in the China market. It's going to take us a few quarters, but we did see sequential share growth in China for PSG’s business in cal
componenttext: In China space, specifically we're really focused on rebuilding our brand and our channel as well obviously our position in the China market. It's going to take us a few quarters, but we did see sequential share growth in China for PSG’s business in calendar Q3 and as Todd mentioned, our desktop and workstation businesses remain strong. So we're confident that we're on the right track.

componenttext: I think as we look at the holiday we are very well positioned in the marketplace. We have a rare products across a range of price points and we'll participate in Black Friday with products across our product line and price point line.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010

componenttext: Question for Todd and if you look at some of your product lines on an individual basis, we're up obviously 50% plus Blades up 51% and ProCurve about 50%. By and large, are these products being sold on an individual basis or is this more of an overall systems approach or solutions approach, if you will, Converged Infrastructure theme, BladeSystem metrics, et cetera? Thanks.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you look at it specifically from the server side what we see is actually both. We see some instances where we have clients who just want to do server refresh and that can get great ROI by upgrading to a G6 or G7 and the return is just so fast that you
componenttext: If you look at it specifically from the server side what we see is actually both. We see some instances where we have clients who just want to do server refresh and that can get great ROI by upgrading to a G6 or G7 and the return is just so fast that you’ll see just pure upgrades. At the same time, we are doing a lot of work around converged infrastructure where we are doing whole modernization of data centers and in those case what you see us doing is putting together a solution that might be a combination of server storage, networking power and cooling, management software, security software and services associated with it to build out the data centers, so just a complete solution. Then we have other instances where we have customers who want to get started with a private cloud and what we have got is the service we call Cloud Start and in Cloud Start what we can do is take our services capability, put together a design for a customer on a private cloud and using our BladeSystem Matrix software along with our services software and our management software actually get them up and running with the private cloud in 30 days. And just as one example, we had a bank in the U.S. that we provided this sort of project for and what they saw was it used to take them months to be able to deploy additional server capacity and now they can do it in two to three hours, so incredible advantages in terms of flexibility and cost. So we are actually seeing this growth come in lots of different flavors in terms of the transactions and then water solution project.

componenttext: Question either for Cathie or VJ. How should we be thinking about the balance between IPG operating margins and unit growth? Operating margin was above 17% in a strong hardware quarter. Is 17 to 17.5 plus the new operating margin target where do you see having to invest more in sales staff, promotions and things like ePrint R&D to help you keep units strong?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, IPG had a strong quarter continued to invest into unit growth and innovation because that's really the driving force for IPG continue to go over revenue. If you look at the unit growth, we want to continue to drive units in 2011. As a matter of f
componenttext: I think, IPG had a strong quarter continued to invest into unit growth and innovation because that's really the driving force for IPG continue to go over revenue. If you look at the unit growth, we want to continue to drive units in 2011. As a matter of fact, we would like to put at least 20% unit growth for laser jets in Q1. As far as the innovation is concerned, the ePrint, we're getting very good receptions. as I have mentioned in our analyst call, 2 million units in Q4 and 5 million units in calendar 2010. We absolutely believe that our innovation that we are driving will help us to drive more supplies growth and really established IPG globally.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: The question is for the floor. I just had a question as far as services growth trajectory here. The 4Q performance, was that kind of in line with what you expected when you kind of tempered the FY '11 forecast related to Services growth and how should we
componenttext: The question is for the floor. I just had a question as far as services growth trajectory here. The 4Q performance, was that kind of in line with what you expected when you kind of tempered the FY '11 forecast related to Services growth and how should we think about that getting jump started? Is it going to be inorganic or organic growth from here?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: You should think of our Services growth as primarily organic growth and as you've heard us say, over the last few quarters we've been very pleased with the signings and Cathie also made the comment that our trailing 12-month book-to-bill is comfortably ab
componenttext:
You should think of our Services growth as primarily organic growth and as you've heard us say, over the last few quarters we've been very pleased with the signings and Cathie also made the comment that our trailing 12-month book-to-bill is comfortably above one. So those are all things that we feel good about. We also feel very good about the quality of the pipeline as well as the size of the pipeline when we look at the deals that are in the funnel. We also have inside the services business, as Leo mentioned at the very beginning, some new innovative services that are in the application space and also some of our industry solutions. 
On top of that, we're continuing to make investments in sales coverage specifically around growing our services business and that includes sales investments in terms of basic support services sold along with products. So, we feel great about all these things and these are all things that as you know build over time and so that's why we have given the guidance that we have. One more thing about the services growth is, it's also important to us in terms of our ability to pull together and integrate solutions and then also on top of that the product pull-through. We've seen our pull-through increase 50% year-over-year and that includes pulling through servers, storage, networking, software, printers and PCs. And since we closed the acquisition of EDS as new deals are solutioned, we have a higher percent of the content that is solutioned with HP. So, that's not specifically services growth, but it's another valuable aspect of services helping our overall portfolio growth.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: So Mark, let me also add that we view our services growth as being roughly in line with the market and that with the continued cost structure improvements that we're making as well as well as the investments that Ann talked about in sales coverage and the
componenttext: So Mark, let me also add that we view our services growth as being roughly in line with the market and that with the continued cost structure improvements that we're making as well as well as the investments that Ann talked about in sales coverage and the new innovative service offerings that we would expect to grow at or above the market in the long term.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Leo, I have a question for you. Could you just talk a little bit more on your initial thoughts on what you are seeing at HP, sort of on a segment basis and how HP is sitting in vis-à-vis the competition? How you think to position vis-à-vis cloud, just i
componenttext: Leo, I have a question for you. Could you just talk a little bit more on your initial thoughts on what you are seeing at HP, sort of on a segment basis and how HP is sitting in vis-à-vis the competition? How you think to position vis-à-vis cloud, just if you could talk maybe segment by segment, what you've seen so far granted it's only been three weeks? How you see the Company position and then how you expect the next year or so to go?

headline: Hewlett-Packard Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's a long question of I'll try to give you a reasonably short answer. HP has many trends and it's actually a formidable company. To name just a few of these trends, I'd like to say the best are our technology portfolio, our scale, our people, our custom
componenttext:
It's a long question of I'll try to give you a reasonably short answer. HP has many trends and it's actually a formidable company. To name just a few of these trends, I'd like to say the best are our technology portfolio, our scale, our people, our customer relationships and our operational excellence. I do believe that our greatest strength is actually our opportunity. Given our size and breadth, we have a unique position in the market to expand to do way more business in emerging markets, to become more of a solution provider for our customers and to leverage our own technology better across the entire company. 
You should bear in mind that as technology trends are moving and are moving rapidly, we at HP have the opportunity to grow our leadership position. We are addressing the cloud in many ways. Example Converged Infrastructure and we are addressing mobility with webOS, so all of these are fantastic opportunities that we are looking at. Our opportunity is also to integrate more of our IP together because ultimately customers don’t actually want to by heart their software or services or whatever else, they want us to help them solve their problems in a more flexible, secure and cost-effective way, and we use our integrated hardware, software and services to do just that. Customers are also not looking just for cloud in exactly the same way as we discussed earlier on. We will continue to deliver solutions in a hybrid environment whether it's on-premise through the cloud or hosted. But with customers who really want a partner who can help them to be more productive, meeting their demand (inaudible) between the 24x7 connected world and you know that's why we launched our Instant-On Solution place [ph], which address exactly this particular need. So, to give you the short of it all and the net of it all, I believe we are extremely well positioned across all of our technologies. 
We have, if you want, a secret formula, a secret source that we can actually put to bear to our advantage. We're the only Company in this industry that is equally good on the consumer side and on the enterprise side. If we manage and we will work very hard to do this to leverage the rapid innovation cycle that occur on the consumer side back into the enterprise, become more robust, most scalable and then use it to our benefit, I think that was an immense competitive advantage which is one of the reasons why we need to spend a little bit more money on R&D and one of the reasons why we need to invest into our sales force, so we can bring all of this to bear in a various factors way to the market. So, net-net I'm very optimistic. Maybe actually closing this call - a few remarks just to close this call out. We are winning in the market and we have a significant opportunity in front of us. We had a very strong Q4 and are confidence that we'd execute Q1 and the years ahead and continue to be focused on our customers, process, and employees, and I look forward to meeting with investors in the coming months. For now, thank you for your time today and have a great day. Thank you.
